TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the light of today's current account figure of a $2.25 billion deficit, the eighth time in the last nine months that it has been over $2 billion, I ask the minister: why should not Australians take notice of the warnings made over the weekend by the chief executive of the ANZ Bank, Don Mercer, that the current account crisis could trigger another recession? Has not Mr Mercer simply highlighted yet again that the Keating budget will do nothing to bring the current account deficit down from six per cent of GDP—the very same level that prompted Mr Keating to warn of the onset of the banana republic before the last recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The balance of payments figures for April 1995 were released at, I think, 11.15 this morning. I want to get the balance of payments figures into the context of this answer because it is important to understand the platform upon which this question was asked. The note I have from the Bureau of Industry Economics says:

ANSWER.PARA: If current account deficits of $2.3 billion to $2.5 billion were to occur for the final two months of the 1994-95 financial year, the current account deficit for the whole of 1994-95 would be slightly lower than the revised Treasury forecast of $27 billion.

That is to say, for all of the reasons that we have given in response to numerous questions in the Senate, the current account has, of course, gone high but it has gone high because we have been sucking in capital goods. It has gone high because we have not been exporting as many mineral commodities, because of lack of demand in the northern hemisphere and because of the effect of the drought. Indeed, the real story of these balance of payments figures—which are below market expectations, I might say—is that the drought impact is now beginning to show up in our current account.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you saying—that it could be worse?

—No, I am saying that the drought affects our ability as an exporting nation to earn export income. That shows up in the current account. It is a reason of nature, not a reason of economics. It is an issue that Australians ought to appreciate. As soon as better climatic conditions affect our rural producers, the economy will come back into a better current account balance than it currently is.

PARA.TAB: In other words, it is not a long-term structural problem for the economy. It is a transitional and climatic one, and it will be one that will be overcome. It is not something about which gloom and doom ought to be spread, nor is it something about which the opposition has ever had a policy. When you have one, maybe you will tell us and the rest of the Australian people. It would come as a terrible shock that you even had one single policy idea, Senator Hill, let alone anything else.
Let me return to the question, which was again in the tradition of this opposition. In trying to spread doom and gloom in the Australian economy when we have the foundation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question was: why shouldn't the government heed the warnings of Mr Mercer? Why shouldn't it listen? Why shouldn't it listen to the messenger? There are no vested interests. It was a sensible comment by a specialist. Why shouldn't you listen?
—You have restated the question. There is obviously no point of order.

—I heard the question, but the question was based on the current account figures and those figures, as presented in the question, were presented erroneously. I therefore took the opportunity to correct the premise—
—Why were the figures erroneous?
—Listen to the way the question was asked. You probably wrote it, Senator Short, which means you got it wrong yet again.

PARA.TAB: The reasons why the government has confidence in the future of the Australian economy are set out in the Treasurer's budget speech; in the expectations of 3 3/4 per cent growth and continuing low inflation for Australia; in the medium-term savings plan we have to improve the level of national savings and, hence, reinvestment in the Australian economy; in the record profit share that we are currently enjoying; in the high jobs growth the Australian economy is going through, with us overshooting our aim in terms of the creation of new jobs; and the improved competitiveness of the Australian economy over the last several years which is positioning us particularly to enable growth of our manufactured exports, which these current account figures show have grown significantly. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think I ought to give the minister a bit more time. I remind him that his budget forecast for next year is a $27 billion deficit, on top of a $27 billion deficit for this year, and that the percentage, as a percentage of GDP, is only going to be reduced marginally. The question is: what ideas do you have? What ideas are you going to implement to bring down the current account deficit? Why will you not listen to the warnings of someone like Don Mercer and actually put into place a policy prescription to address this critical issue?

—Mr President, you could equally say of the opposition: why do you not actually pay attention to the structure of the economy, the changes we have made, the dividends that that is beginning to pay? Why would we start with an odd criticism from this corner or that corner when we have a long-term strategy for this economy and when, palpably, the opposition does not, never has had and has not yet produced one single new policy idea?

PARA.TAB: With regard to the level of the current account deficit, it is true that in money terms the figure forecast in this year's budget will be the same in the next out-year. But, of course, the economy will have grown so that in percentage terms the current account deficit will have fallen. That is a very fundamental question, Senator Hill. In other words, to put it simply for you, we will have improved our economic position. Perhaps for once in its life the opposition should stand up and recognise that and pay some credence to it in public debate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Yesterday, the minister launched the new Commonwealth coastal policy entitled Living on the coast. Can the minister inform the Senate how this new policy will contribute to the protection of Australia's coastline?

—The $53 million package which I launched yesterday, the Commonwealth's coastal policy, Living on the coast, is a very significant commitment to better coastal management, coming as it does on top of a range of other Commonwealth initiatives. These include $14 million extra funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, a $5 million national wetlands program, and earlier decisions, such as the saving of Jervis Bay and Shoalwater Bay. The biggest part of this package, Coastcare, will see $23 1/2 million spent on empowering community organisations to do hands-on work to protect and restore our coastal environments. It will also strengthen partnerships between community groups and local government and thus will increase participation in local planning and decision making.

PARA.TAB: The universally acknowledged problem of scattered and uncoordinated decision making will be addressed not by legislation but by $8.4 million provided through the Department of Housing and Regional Development, to add value to existing planning mechanisms by ensuring that all relevant parties in a region contribute to a single, integrated planning process. What we can achieve with cooperation is agreement about the future use of important areas and certainty about agreed outcomes.

It is essential that coastal zone managers, planners, professionals and local communities have the skills to deal with coastal issues. The coastal action program includes more than $8 million to provide improved professional development and training opportunities, focus research on management problems, expand coastal monitoring and improve access to information.

Living on the coast presents the Commonwealth's vision for a cooperative integrated approach to coastal management. The Commonwealth will make sure that its own coastal activities are managed sustainably. The coastal policy sets out objectives and principles which will guide the activities of all Commonwealth agencies, giving for the first time clear guidance on their responsibilities in the coastal zone.

In launching the policy yesterday, I said that it is not an instant solution to coastal problems but is an excellent and comprehensive attack on the key problems and, importantly, is one that has the support of all the key stakeholders. I think this integrated cooperative approach to coastal management really has been received as a vision for the future for coasts and coastal protection in Australia. It is obvious that this package will mean that all stakeholders will be able to play their part in coastal management and ensure that we have ecologically sustainable management of our coasts in Australia. I think we will see all those involved in the coastal zone really take advantage of these opportunities. We have to remember that protection of our coasts is not only of local and regional significance but is of national and global importance. I believe the Commonwealth's coastal policy, Living on the coast, will deliver the goods.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Two leading industry groups, the Master Builders Association and the Housing Industry Association, have accused his government of underestimating the tax take from the new 12 per cent sales tax on building materials by an incredible figure of $300 million. As former Treasurer Dawkins admitted that he deliberately fudged the 1993 budget sales and petrol tax revenue figures, what guarantees do Australians have that the government is not continuing that practice in this year's budget? Does the government stand by its figures? Will the minister release the methodology, figures and calculations used by Treasury in reaching its revenue forecasts for the building materials sales taxes or are you, in reality, just trying to hide the impact of those taxes on an industry that is already suffering a 25 per cent decline in building approvals? (Time expired)

—I would probably suggest that Senator Tambling go outside the parliament and make that observation about former Treasurer Dawkins because I am not sure that Mr Dawkins would ever agree that he has engaged in what Senator Tambling accused him of.
—He said it.
—You should go and read what he did say and not try to make up words and put into his mouth what you hope he would have said in order to try to score a political point.

PARA.TAB: This question is about whether we stand by the budget estimates. Of course we do. I remind the Senate that at the time of last year's budget—about the first or second week after the budget—all sorts of people were running around with estimates about whether or not the budget forecasts were true. Indeed, that is what we expect as normal behaviour as industry and the community react to what Treasury has come forward with as reasonable estimates of growth and change. The most outstanding one I commend to the chamber for its attention now is the estimates promoted in the previous budget on investment in Australia. We were told that we were wildly inaccurate, that we could not possibly be right and that we would be absolutely shown to be wrong. In fact, we were a bit conservative and we did underestimate. For all the expert voices out there telling us that we were wrong, Treasury was closer to the outcome than just about anyone else. Do we stand by the estimates in this year's budget? Yes, we do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister failed to address that part of my question where I asked whether he will release the methodology, calculations and figures used. That is very important in light of an article in today's paper, where the Treasury official acknowledges that `we made our calculations based on our methodology and we stick by them'. If that is the case, why will the minister not table the revenue forecasts of the Treasury and acknowledge that they are flawed?

—They are not flawed. The simple reason why I will not admit that they are flawed is that I would be misleading the parliament if I did. I tell the truth; they are not flawed. They are based on tried and true methodology. Senator Tambling should not come in here and make allegations like that; they are ridiculous.

PARA.TAB: Will the methodology be released? My understanding is that Treasury methodology is consistent and well-known and frequently adduced in estimates proceedings, in which this chamber is about to engage. Senator Tambling may well have an opportunity to directly ask Treasury about its methodology point by point. He might learn something if he does. I do not think there is any great mystery about methodology.

I conclude on the merit of this argument: our estimate puts the figure at about $400. Under the opposition's GST, were Senator Tambling's party elected at the last election, Australian taxpayers would have had to pay $4,000. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, concerns the efforts of government and industry within Australia to resume the live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia. Given the fate of the most recent shipment, can the minister advise what steps he has taken to review the future of such trade?

—As honourable senators would be aware, the export of live sheep from Australia to Saudi Arabia ceased at the end of 1990 following difficulties with rejections of Australian shipments because of the incidence of scabby mouth. Earlier this year, the Saudi requirements for the resumption of this trade were encapsulated in a set of broad conditions that the Australian live sheep industry would adhere to before the AMLC would approve shipments of live sheep to Saudi Arabia. Despite the systems put in place, there was an outbreak of scabby mouth on the first shipment that departed Fremantle on 15 April. The AMLC advised me that the trader decided to divert the ship to Aqaba in early May because of an outbreak of the disease.

PARA.TAB: The fate of the first shipment has raised, as far as I am concerned, a number of serious issues. These include the epidemiology of the disease, the quality assurance systems that were put into place, the issue of sheep selection and age, the impact of on-board conditions on the ability to deliver within specifications and animal welfare considerations. All of these must be examined, as far as I am concerned, in detail before further shipments will be approved.

Following receipt by me of a report from the AMLC on the latest shipment, I have decided to form a working group on live sheep to Saudi Arabia to perform the task. It will include senior representatives from the AMLC, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the live sheep industry. I have already had discussions on this matter with the Western Australian Minister for Primary Industry, Monty House. I will invite him, as a result of those discussions, to nominate a senior representative from Western Australia to attend those working group meetings. This invitation will be extended to other interested states. The state that is most likely to be interested, in addition to Western Australia, is South Australia. Once I have received a report from the working group, I will then reconsider the matter of live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia. I table the terms of reference for the working group.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Is the minister aware that there has been logging activity in the Sharpe block north of Walpole in Western Australia, despite its interim listing on the register of the national estate and despite nearly all of it being protected in the 1995 round of woodchip licences? Is he also aware that the Australian Heritage Commission has admitted that it left off coupe 6 of the Sharpe block because of an oversight? I also refer him to a letter addressed to the Prime Minister from conservationists in Western Australia, where they state that a report on illegal logging in coupes 7 and 8 of the Giblett block has been presented to the Minister for Resources. Does he agree that, since the minister has repeatedly stated publicly that such breaches will be regarded seriously and appropriate action will be taken, appropriate action could well be that rights to the Sharpe coupe 6 are forsaken because of the illegal exporting of chips by the same company in Giblett blocks 7 and 8?

—The advice I have from the Minister for Resources in respect of the Sharpe block is as follows. In approving logging in and the export of woodchips from Sharpe coupe 6, the Minister for Resources fully complied with his obligation in respect of the Australian Heritage Commission Act. Sharpe 6, together with other Western Australian national estate coupes proposed for logging in 1995, was referred to the Australian Heritage Commission for comment on 20 October 1994, and the commission provided its comments six weeks later on 5 December 1994. Sharpe 6 was on the list of coupes originally provided by the Minister for Resources to the environment department for its consideration. Something that Senator Bell may find of interest—I certainly found it of interest—is that Sharpe 6 was never nominated by the conservation groups for inclusion in the government's interim protection list.
—Must be the only one they missed.

—It must be; nevertheless, they missed it. It would appear to be inconsistent that these groups now suggest, after the assessment of the 509 coupes has been completed, that consideration of Sharpe 6 should be reopened when they did not include it on their original list.
—I need to have the minister clearly answer this: will you stop the proposed logging of coupe 6 of the Sharpe block?

—Mr President, I have given Senator Bell and the Senate the advice I received from the Minister for Resources. The other parts of Senator Bell's question I will refer to the minister and I will advise the Senate accordingly.

—Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. With reference to the recently reported killing of 37 villagers at the Freeport mine in West Papua and to the minister's statement, reported on 7 April 1995 in the Financial Review, that the Australian Embassy in Jakarta had been ordered to urgently investigate the killings, I ask: first, what steps has the Australian government and, in particular, the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, taken to establish and validate this incident at the Freeport mine which allegedly involved Indonesian troops and private security forces employed by the Freeport mine; and, secondly, can the minister confirm that the International Red Cross has visited West Papua to investigate the killings and, if so, what were its findings?

—Mr President, following the release of the ACFOA report on 5 April, the Australian Embassy made representations on the allegations to the Indonesian government outlining our serious concerns. The Indonesian government undertook to provide information to our embassy, and the embassy has been instructed, as I have previously indicated, to follow up on this undertaking.

PARA.TAB: We have also sought independent information about the situation in the Tembagapura area surrounding the Freeport mine. Our inquiries so far indicate that a number of deaths did occur in the area as a result of actions carried out by the Indonesian armed forces but that the number and circumstances of those deaths are still unconfirmed.

The incidents appear to have occurred after the Indonesian armed forces increased their presence in the area after the killing of an Irianese Freeport employee, allegedly by secessionist forces, the OPM. The Indonesian government has issued a statement acknowledging that there have been casualties from actions by the security authorities in Irian Jaya but claims that ACFOA's report of 37 fatalities is greatly exaggerated. Accordingly, we are continuing to see if we can get to the truth of this matter.

As to the second question about the ICRC, we do keep in touch, through our embassy in Jakarta, with the Red Cross in Indonesia, which, I understand, monitors developments in that country, including in Irian Jaya. I am not at liberty to pass on the content of our communications with the ICRC because such information is normally provided on a confidential basis. I would certainly be happy to ask the ICRC if it has any information to pass on in this instance, if that has not already happened. I suggest to the senator that she might like to approach that organisation herself in connection with the information that she seeks.

Finally, I can indicate that the Australian Ambassador in Jakarta is now planning to visit Irian Jaya, including the Freeport mine area, in July. This will provide an opportunity to gain first-hand impressions of the situation in the province. If I do get any further, harder information on these matters—in which, I can assure the senator, I am equally interested—I will certainly make it available to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. Why has the government taken so long to get accurate information on the Freeport killings? If the findings of the Australian government are damaging, as they may appear to be, will the government be abandoning its policy of joint military exercises and helping to train Indonesian army units?

—As I have reminded the senator on a number of occasions, the Australian government does not have the capacity to mount independent investigations into these sorts of matters. Our access to such information is obviously limited. We do the best we can, working through the Indonesian authorities, and certainly through, to the extent that we can, such independent sources of information as the ICRC. In the event that information were to come to hand suggesting involvement by the military in killings on a greater scale than that which seems to have been the case on the public record, at least so far, I guess our response will be the same as it has been to similar examples of default or misbehaviour by the Indonesian military in the past. We have to make an independent judgment as to the extent to which other interests that we are pursuing in Indonesia and in the region as a whole should be prejudiced as a result of the misbehaviour of particular individuals within those armed forces in a situation where there has been no central direction, as seems to be the case here. (Time expired)

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, when did you learn of the offer to Senator Bruce Childs of a diplomatic posting if he retired from the Senate to make way for metalworkers union boss and Keating supporter, Mr George Campbell? Did you approve of the offer to Senator Childs?

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister what, if any, role does Mr Leo McLeay play in diplomatic appointments? Was this offer to Senator Childs made to enhance the entry into the Senate of a Mr George Campbell, whom Mr Keating described in 1986 as one who would carry the jobs of dead men around his neck for an eternity because of his aggressive industrial activities? —Mr Keating has described all of us in terms that I would not care to recount on this occasion, and I think under those circumstances it pales into moderation what he might have said about his colleagues on the New South Wales Right—if he did indeed say that which is attributed to him, which I, of course, would very much doubt because it is so out of character, as we know. As to the first question: I, of course, have the greatest respect for my colleague, Leo McLeay, but to date, anyway, that respect has not extended to accepting his advice, let alone his direction, on matters related to diplomatic appointments.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Media reports of the meeting in Manilla of the Cairns Group of agricultural fair trading countries on 26 and 27 May indicate that the group remains committed to operating as a force for agricultural trade liberalisation. Can the minister advise the Senate of the outcome of this meeting and the implications for the Australian rural sector and how these fit in with his recent meetings with the OECD and discussions with the European Commission on renewed efforts to liberalise international trade following the Uruguay Round?

—I again welcome the European delegation. The meeting of the Cairns Group of ministers in Manilla established a basis for a renewed international effort to address barriers to Australian agricultural exporters and agricultural exporters of other fair trading countries. It underlines the importance of the Cairns Group to our efforts to secure better access for Australia's agricultural exports and better returns for our exporters. It makes it very clear the Cairns Group is not satisfied with the result of the Uruguay Round.

PARA.TAB: The ministers essentially set two goals. One goal which would seem self-evident but the significance of which should not be underestimated is to focus squarely on ensuring that people fully abide by the commitments they entered into in the Uruguay Round. That sounds like something that is so obvious it does not need saying, but early experience suggests that matter requires a lot of attention and scrutiny. We intend to make sure it receives it.

The issue to which I wish to refer today is the second priority set by the ministers; that is, to begin to develop a new agenda for further freeing up world trade in agriculture and a commitment over the next 12 months to develop a program which we will submit to the 1996 ministerial conference on the WTO in Singapore. That will be a very important opportunity to push forward the issue of agricultural trade liberalisation. Over the next 12 months, we will be developing the Cairns Group goals for that further liberalisation.

The other item thing to which we wish to give emphasis and which flows logically from that point is the importance of the major markets and major economies opening up further their markets as a result of their domestic policies. Most particularly in 1995 this will be important in the United States because it is developing its new farm bill, which is before Congress. It is also important in terms of the reform of the common agricultural policy of the European Union about which I have been making representations in Brussels. We welcome the views expressed by the current president of the European Union that the enlargement of the EU will necessitate reform of the common agricultural policy. Logic has demanded it for a long time, but enlargement will make it more necessary and inevitable.

We are looking to build momentum quickly for further agricultural trade reform to open up free trade in agriculture. It is not just good for our exporters; it has a rather good outcome for the importing countries as well. It is called cheaper food for their citizens. Australia has always had a rather naive view that it is a very good policy for governments to try to make food for its citizens cheaper. We have never worked out the logic of the countries which think it is a great policy initiative to make sure all their people can pay a lot more than they need to for their food. I have never worked out why that is a good policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you convincing our guests?
—I am sure that they would be able to explain it to us if we were to give them the opportunity. We all look forward to that explanation, but I have not yet heard it.

PARA.TAB: We are under no illusion that the issue of reform of agricultural policy will be easy. There is massive resistance to it. It is in the interests of the agricultural consumers of those countries in question, but the producers have more lobbying power. It is time that governments in the major economies resisted that lobbying power and acted in the interests of their citizens as well as our farmers. The Cairns Group is a very vital step in that regard. Australia will be working to develop our objectives. I will be meeting with the NFF this week to begin the process of identifying Australia's objectives in the development of this new international agenda for agricultural trade liberalisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the minister aware that the National Press Club has extended an invitation to Taiwan's President Lee Teng-Hui to deliver an address at the club? Will the government grant a visa to Mr Lee to enter Australia for this purpose?

—Notwithstanding recent developments in the United States, the government has not been contemplating a visit, whether unofficial or otherwise, to Australia by President Lee Teng-Hui or for that matter by Premier Lien Chan, who has also been the subject of some speculation in this respect. It has been the policy of the Australian government, as Senator Chapman should be aware, to restrict private visits to Australia by high level officials from Taiwan to those which are strictly related to the promotion of our strong and expanding economic and trade interests between the two of us. A visit by President Lee, or for that matter Premier Lien Chan, even if private, would be of a political nature and not consistent with the current state of our unofficial links with Taiwan.

PARA.TAB: Against the background of Australia's position that the PRC is the sole legal government of China, the Australian government does support the development of unofficial contacts with Taiwan in the pursuit of our economic, commercial and other interests. Those contacts have been multiplying in recent years as Taiwan has becomes our seventh largest trading partner, our sixth largest export market and our fourth largest trading partner in the whole of Asia. Unofficial contacts in the past in pursuit of our economic and commercial interests have included private visits to Taiwan in October 1992 by Mr Griffiths, then Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources, in November 1993 by Senator Cook, then Minister for Trade, and in July 1994 by Minister Lee as Minister for Tourism. A number of Taiwanese ministers have also made unofficial visits to Australia. These visits have been in an unofficial and private capacity only and do not reflect any change in Australia's one-China policy. That is the situation as it now stands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The minister, in his response, indicated that unofficial visits by Taiwanese ministers were acceptable. I put it to him that the visit by Mr Lee in relation to an address to the National Press Club could certainly be characterised in that way. He is not coming here for any official meetings with government representatives or government officials in Australia; it is an unofficial visit. Therefore, why would the same rules not apply to that as have applied in the United States with his visit to his alma mater?

—Senator Chapman does not seem to have been listening—that is not an unusual state of affairs. I said there is a distinction between those ministers who have been involved in expanding or developing our economic and trade interests, and those whose role in the Taiwanese system is squarely, quintessentially and unmistakably political. There is no question but that an unofficial visit by either the president or the premier would be seen as qualitatively different in that respect from an unofficial visit by other ministers or officials whose responsibilities much more immediately and squarely are directed towards trade matters which have been the subject of such visits in the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to the submission by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology to the tripartite working group on labour standards in the Asia-Pacific region, established in response to my motion on child labour which was passed by the Senate in September last year. First, is the minister aware that his department suggests that no government action should be taken on the exploitation of children because, amongst other reasons, of the `potential negative consequences for Australian industry and consumers in limiting their access to competitively priced products on the domestic market?' Secondly, does the minister reject his department's apparent belief that Australian consumers would want to benefit from the suffering of children forced to work under horrendous conditions which destroy their health and often their lives? Is this the sort of change to Australia's values which would make us more acceptable to Mr Mahathir? Does the minister favour—(Time expired)

—The tripartite working group was established on the initiative of the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, in response to a range of voices calling for such a committee. One of those voices I think was yours, Senator—certainly there were voices within the Australian Labor Party. As I understand it, the group was set up by Senator McMullan in order to address this question. My department, at an interdepartmental level, was called upon to write a report on the operational mechanisms that could be used to implement certain strategies to express our repugnance as a nation at child labour and forced labour.

PARA.TAB: On where we stand, we have been looking at what we are going to do about it. The Australian Customs Service is incorporated within my department, the Department of Industry, Science and Technology; so the submission was on a joint Customs-departmental basis. The submission focused on operational issues rather than symbolic ones and commented on the effectiveness of certain actions. It surveyed what has happened around the world with the unilateral blocking of imports; how easy or difficult this is to do and what the cost impacts are. So it is against that background that you ask this question.

Your first part of the question is about the department's view on whether it is going to cost Australians more and whether that is the reason for inaction. The department, in its submission, recommends action; so I do not think it is fair to say, as you did in the first part of your question, that it is proposing no action. That is not the case. It is proposing actions that it believes will be effective and suggests that an industry code of conduct, which puts the onus on importers to satisfy themselves that no forced or child labour has been used in their products, would be a useful step. That is a suggestion that I think you have also made, Senator. The department endorses that, so I do not think it is fair to characterise it as having a non-action, let us not do anything, view.

Your second question is based again, I think, on an erroneous premise that my department has an apparent view that it should not do anything. That is not true. But it does distinguish between symbolic gestures and things that might have a real effect. I am not dismissing the importance of symbolism in an issue like this. However, in deciding between options, one would obviously think that the best options would be those that would have an effect that would bring about change rather than simply those that would have the effect of Australia declaring itself symbolically for change but not being able to deliver it and imposing on Australia and its economy high costs for that type of gesture. So we were looking at applied ways of doing things and weighing the costs against the effectiveness—not the cost of this against the advantage to the country but whether or not we would address the real issue.

What is my view of all this? My view of all this is that I have long stood for opposition to child enforced labour all of my professional life and that remains my position—and that is the government's position. What will we explicitly do? We will obviously await the outcome of this tripartite report. We will listen intently to the recommendations Senator McMullan makes and I am sure they will be considered and useful. But then we will direct our mind to that to achieve the best possible outcome to put down this repugnant practice where it occurs throughout this region and elsewhere in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his generally positive response. It is unfortunate that the department nevertheless thought to emphasise the point that it would cost Australians more if they refused to buy cheap products made by child labour—I think that is part of its thinking and that is regrettable. However, I ask: does the minister favour government action to clearly and properly identify imports made by child labour so that Australian consumers can make an informed choice?
—On the first part, it is not a core view of my department. Its motive is to join with the rest of us in doing something about this.
—Do you have core views and peripheral views?

—No. But in canvassing actions and reactions, they would be complete in the presentation of all the possible consequences, as would any economists when they got down to write a paper about what a certain thing would do to the rest of the economy. And it is in that context, not in the context of their not wishing to achieve change here, that you should read those comments, I believe.

PARA.TAB: Do I see the need to do something here to help improve the situation? As I said the last time I stood up: yes, I do. It is a question of marrying effectiveness and achieveability to create real change and put an end to this practice.I would certainly want to see Australian consumers be aware of how they themselves might, by consumer choice, effect that sort of change. If some things can be done to help that, then I am sure that will be part of Senator McMullan's recommendations to us. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, really!

It is quite clear that every time recommendations come into this parliament to strengthen the power in relation to unconscionable conduct—the power for small business to have a better chance against big business—the Liberal Party falls at the first hurdle. Senator Tierney, at the meeting I explained that, as a result of representations made to me at the last two meetings of the Small Business Forum, we have now got a working party looking at amendments to the unconscionable conduct provisions. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. The only lie that was perpetrated was by Senator Woods going out to the community and trying to scare non-government schools in particular. Why was he doing this back in March? It was part of his effort to try to help the Fahey government get re-elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In the interest of common standards, I ask the Senator to withdraw that earlier reference to a lie.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. On what grounds and on whose initiative have visa laws been relaxed to allow Indonesian tourists to visit the Christmas Island casino without formally applying for a visa prior to their arrival? Why does such a change apply only to Christmas Island and not to Western Australia? Is the minister proposing to take similar action for other casinos in Australia? Will similar treatment be afforded to other nationalities?

—The issue Senator Knowles refers to is essentially a continuation of a special arrangement which was put in place when Christmas Island casino was to be built. It was my decision to reintroduce the visa-free entry to the island. It was a decision taken in recognition of the fact that the island is so isolated from Australia on the one hand and is so close to a market on the other. In fact, it has attracted this market over recent years.

PARA.TAB: In the lead-up to the decision, extensive consultations have taken place with key agencies, including the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service, the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories and my department. This was before the decision was made. Because of the island's isolation, we thought we could protect our borders and, at the same time, pick up the economic advantage which only Christmas Island would be able to pick up. As a consequence, both in respect of the first decision, which was taken some time in 1986, and the more recent decision, which I took towards the end of last year, our confidence in the potential to be realised has been met. The initiative, for instance, has seen the construction of a five star hotel casino with some 156 rooms on the island by the Christmas Island Resort Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which everyone was predicting would fail.

—As Senator Collins said, everyone at the time was predicting that it would fail. The targeted clientele are very much that clientele in the Indonesian provinces which are not easily serviced and are remote from Jakarta.

PARA.TAB: So, as I said, there were economic interests and there is no loss to the integrity of Australian borders. The assessment has been, both in respect of the first decision and this one, that the market this casino is attracting is a market that would otherwise not be available to Australia. As a consequence, this decision was made by me both in the first instance and in more recent days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is it not correct to say that this is not a continuation of an existing policy and that the policy was actually terminated in March 1994? I therefore ask you why you reinstituted the policy. Is it at the expense of the states and territories who will stand to lose a large amount of tax revenue while the Commonwealth, your government, reaps the reward of the tax revenue of the increased tourism into Christmas Island? Will you be doing anything for the other states and territories that I mentioned in my original question, and will you be extending this entitlement to other nationalities?

—I think I have actually answered most of the questions that Senator Knowles has repeated in her supplementary question. I did say it was reinstituted; I did not say it was continued. I did say it was not at the expense of others, and the initial trial period reflected that. The resort has been picking up people who otherwise would not have access to our visa processing and who also would not make the trip to other casinos in Australia. That was the rationale in the first instance; that is the rationale in the second instance; and, as I say, it is actually producing benefits.

PARA.TAB: The other attraction, of course, is that as the island is so remote, people travelling to that island to come to other parts of Australia have to get a visa for entry to the rest of Australia. That is something that can be easily policed from there and something that cannot be policed from other parts of Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Intelligence Arrangements with the United States

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In light of the numerous press reports suggesting that Australia has been prepared to enter into an intelligence arrangement with the United States in which the information obtained in Australia is not fully shared with Australia, can the minister comment on the policy issues involved?

—Senator Murphy knows very well that in keeping with the practice of successive Australian governments I can make no comment on specific reports or allegations relating to matters of national security. That is a tradition which I intend strictly to observe no matter how ill-founded or inaccurate might be the reports which generate questions on these matters.

PARA.TAB: But, while I have nothing to say about the particular reports and allegations in the press, Senator Murphy's question does raise a more general policy issue to which I can and should respond. I am concerned about any suggestion that the government in any instance or circumstances did not give absolute priority to Australia's national interests. Whether it be trade-related issues such as the Uruguay Round or defence and security cooperation, the government ensures that Australian national interests will always come first.

Let me further say just this: to the extent that the government does ever engage in cooperative intelligence activities in Australia, then it is our firm policy to require not only our full knowledge of and concurrence to all the detail of such activities, but also full access to all product that might come from them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It does not touch upon the area that Senator Murphy has just asked about but, rather, Australia's embassies overseas. Does the government accept the fact that foreign countries target Australia's overseas embassies with bugging devices in order to make interceptions which compromise Australia's national interest? If so, this Australian government has been abysmally incompetent in not detecting and eradicating foreign bugging of the Australian embassies in Moscow, Beijing, Warsaw, Belgrade, Ankara, Hanoi, Rangoon, Brasilia and Jakarta. I ask the foreign minister: should not the Australian public put down this incompetent government for failing to protect Australia's national interests?

—Again I have to preface my answer by saying that it is the policy of the Australian government, which I strongly uphold, to neither confirm nor deny specific reports or allegations relating to such security and intelligence issues. However, more generally again I can say this, as I did in answer to the last question, despite the cackles and idiocy from the other side: the government attaches great importance—
—I can't answer that.
—Senator Giggle sitting there in the front—exactly. The legion of soft cushions on which you have not made an impression.

PARA.TAB: The government attaches great importance to the security of its embassies abroad, the information they contain and the people who work in them. As part of its normal protective security activities the department has a technical security capability which does seek to maintain the integrity of our missions abroad. It is normal practice to investigate thoroughly all suspicious incidents and/or allegations, wherever they occur. The department is constantly reviewing and modifying countermeasures at posts abroad to keep pace with advancing technology. It is also actively engaged in programs to raise levels of security awareness and compliance amongst its officers. We are confident of the security of our cryptographic systems and the integrity of the procedures related to their use.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the minister at least give an assurance to the parliament that the foreign bugging devices have now been eliminated from making interceptions at our embassies in Moscow, Beijing, Warsaw, Belgrade, Ankara, Hanoi, Rangoon, Brasilia and Jakarta?

—Senator Teague knows perfectly well that to respond to any specific situation which may be alleged to have occurred in any particular country would be to involve me necessarily in a breach of the neither confirm nor deny policy which it is important for all governments—whatever their stripe or colour—to continue to maintain. That said, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 11 May 1995, I present answers to questions on notice Nos. 2048 to 2052.

—Senator Boswell asked me a question without notice on 11 May regarding Japanese encephalitis on Badu Island. I have been provided with further information. The control of communicable diseases is a state responsibility. The Communicable Diseases Network Australia and New Zealand—the network—under the auspices of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, AHMAC, coordinate national outbreak control activities.

PARA.TAB: Individual states and territories may request AHMAC, via the network, for funds to be provided to assist in the management of an outbreak considered to be of national significance. At this time no funds have been requested by the Queensland government for management of the outbreak. However, the network is continuing to liaise closely with the Queensland health department on this matter. I am not sure whether that was terribly much extra information, but I was provided that to pass on to Senator Boswell.

Also, I was asked a question by Senator Coulter on 11 May regarding matters related to Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The following information is provided. The broad categories for membership of the scientific research subcommittee, SRSC, of the National Pituitary Hormone Advisory Council were discussed and agreed at the first meeting of the NPHAC on 17 February 1995. These categories are: the chair of the subcommittee and a medical research expert already appointed to the NHPAC, Professor Ken Donald; the scientific research member of the NPHAC and a virologist, Professor Tony Cunningham; a pathologist; a neurologist; and a sociologist.

The executive committee of the NPHAC, which includes a representative of the pituitary hormone recipient community considered appropriate appointments to the remaining three categories of membership of the SRSC and agreed to Professor Colin Masters, Dr Andrew Hughes and Professor Linda Rosenman, respectively. These are all well-recognised current experts in their fields. Dr Whitten is a retired public servant with scientific qualifications which do not fit the categories of membership for the SRSC as determined by the NPHAC. The membership of the SRSC was endorsed by the second plenary meeting of the National Pituitary Hormones Advisory Council on 12 May. There are six representatives of the hormone recipients community on that council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the balance of payments.

SPEECH.PARA: One reason why this government deserves to be thrown out of office is its total failure to address the current account crisis that we now face. It was demonstrated again today by Senator Cook, who simply was not able to provide any answer at all as to what the government would do to reduce that current account deficit. The figure which came out today indicated another $2.25 billion deficit—the eighth deficit over $2 billion in the last nine months.

PARA.TAB: Let us reflect back to 1986, when the current account deficit in this country was running at an annual rate of $12 billion a year and foreign debt was $85 billion. That is when Mr Paul Keating said that we were headed towards a banana republic. That is when the current account figure was somewhere near six per cent of GDP. Where are we now, some nine years later? Our current account deficit has gone from $12 billion annually to $27 billion and is expected, on the government's own figures, to be $27 billion next year. Our foreign debt has gone from $82 billion to $162 billion.

We are in exactly the same cycle as we were before—the current account out of control, month after month, with debt levels that simply cannot be sustained, leading to ever increasing foreign debt, pressure on interest rates and great concern for the economic future of this country. Of course, as a percentage of GDP, it is back up to Mr Keating's banana republic figure of six per cent. The government's own forecast in this budget only puts the reduction to 5.5 per cent. That is, if everything goes right for the government in this next year—and there is not much economically going right now—it will only be marginally reduced, still at an unsustainable level.

It is more than reasonable, therefore, that we ask the Minister representing the Treasurer what the government is going to do about it. He was simply not able to give a satisfactory answer. He muttered something about the fact that it is to do with sucking in capital goods. In fact, it seems that, in this month's figures, the percentage made up of capital goods has been reduced. It is an unsatisfactory answer.

I come back to the messengers because it is not just us who have been saying this to the government. Time after time it has been said by respected economists and respected business people in the community that this level of deficit, this level of debt, simply cannot be sustained. I remind the Senate of what Mr Don Mercer said this last weekend, which was the basis of the question that was asked. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think our current account is a serious weakness and I could talk about that for some time. What is particularly disturbing about it is that it is showing no signs of improvement. . . . we have to service the debt we've already got.
Something in excess of two per cent of GNP is where we need to be . . .
He was asked: what is the consequence if we do not get it right? Don Mercer, from the ANZ Bank, a highly respected economic commentator in our community, said:
Do you remember the banana republic; the recession we had to have? We have another one of those.
But is the government listening to that? Of course, it is not. Mr Mercer said—and he is absolutely correct:
And each time we go through that experience we come up with higher underlying debt, higher underlying structural unemployment and with basically a lot of problems that we don't need.

He is not the only business leader to have been saying it in recent times. I remind the Senate also of the words of Mr Ian Salmon, the Chairman of the Business Council of Australia, who, only a few days ago, delivered an important speech in this city in which he particularly addressed the budget and the failure, in his terms, of the budget to deliver more growth and prosperity to Australia. He said:
The budget does nothing to lift the growth in Australia to the sort of level that is necessary if we are going to return this country to the top 10 of wealthy nations by the year 2010.
That is a reasonable objective on the part of the Business Council of Australia. He said:
The budget does nothing to improve national savings for the year 1995 and 1996.

He also made the point in passing that the little fiscal tightening that is in the budget is a responsibility that has actually been passed on to business to bear rather than government taking its share of the burden. He is, of course, talking about a budget that so substantially increases taxation. It is a crisis that is facing this country. It is a tragedy that this government, in its last months in office, is not prepared to address it seriously. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is simply no justification for the kind of crisis talk that is generated like a wind machine on occasions like this by Senator Hill, who no doubt will be followed by Senator Short. For every comment of an alarmist kind from someone like Don Mercer, we can find a much more measured and balanced comment from someone like Don Stammer, for example, who I saw and heard on television this morning making a very different analysis of the present situation.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit fell slightly in April due to a fall in the merchandise trade deficit driven by a fall in imports. It is the case that the dollar figure remained high with the $2.4 billion current account deficit figure in December and the $2.3 billion one in January being the highest monthly deficits on record. In absolute terms, they are clearly not the highest as a proportion of GDP. If you go back to 1989-90, you can see monthly deficits of close to this amount being recorded on at least a couple of occasions when nominal GDP was obviously very much lower. That is also true for the period back in the mid-1980s—1986—that Senator Hill was waxing indignant about.

We do take very seriously the issue of the current account deficit. The 1995-96 budget included major structural initiatives that will reduce that deficit in both the short term and the longer term. The government did undertake a significant tightening, as we all should be aware, of fiscal policy in the May budget—a dramatic tightening, in fact—and also introduced superannuation initiatives to boost national saving and to reduce Australia's call on overseas capital. That is the crucial need when we are talking about the current account—taking measures right across the spectrum to boost savings to reduce the call on overseas capital.

In the very short term it is the case next year that the nominal deficit is expected to remain unchanged at $27 million but because of GDP growth that will fall to 5 1/2 per cent of GDP from six per cent this year. The trend is going in that direction and the other substantial structural measures will continue to cut in and work away to produce a further decline.

More important than the size of the deficit is its composition and the circumstances that have led to its change. Let me mention them: first, there has been a surge in imports of capital equipment, which is part of the general surge in productive investment associated with a very strong economy. Investments now forecast to grow by an extraordinarily strong 23 per cent in 1994-95 and of course this is sucking in imports of capital equipment. Secondly, we face the problem of the unsynchronised nature of the world recovery, which has meant that Australian demand for imports has picked up ahead of world demand for Australian exports. While the US economy has also experienced very strong growth, Germany, for example, has thus far experienced a much more subdued and less broad-based recovery and Japan is only just now recovering from the recession.

Thirdly, there has been a structural change in the economy, such as the fact that as a result of tariff reform we are in a transition phase on the path to greater export diversity with the initial impact being of raising import intensity. Falling world commodity prices have seen Australia's terms of trade decline over the last several decades, making it harder to balance our trade without structural reform on the export side. A fourth consideration is, as Senator Cook pointed out, the drought, which is continuing to adversely affect rural exports. They fell eight per cent in seasonally adjusted terms in April, reflecting that weakness in the rural sector. That is there before our eyes—an eight per cent fall in April, directly attributable to the drought. Finally, there is the rise in world interest rates, which add to debt servicing costs and the net income deficit.

In response to all of these phenomena, it is important to appreciate the way in which our manufacturing export base does continue to expand. It continues to respond very well to the improved economic environment. Our international competitiveness has improved by nearly 40 per cent since the early 1980s and has been further helped by low inflation and wage rises and strong productivity growth. Exports, in particular, of elaborately transformed manufactures, which are the real indicator of the strength and sophistication of the Australian economy, grew by 13 per cent through 1994.

So the overall situation is really very strong so far as the basic fundamentals of the Australian economy are concerned. For a whole variety of reasons we do have an acknowledged current account deficit problem. That is the only thing the opposition can find to get its rocks off about at the moment because that is the only aspect of the economy which is not showing starkly and clearly the returns that we would ideally like. But we have put in place the structural changes that are necessary to address that in the longer term and in the short term we can be reasonably confident that there will be a significant turnaround. It is already happening now and will continue to happen in the next financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing that most disturbs me and most Australians in listening to people like Senator Cook and Senator Gareth Evans is the absolutely frightening complacency that the government is showing towards the overwhelming economic problem that we have with our external accounts. Along with that frightening complacency is the equally disturbing lack of any basic understanding of, firstly, the problem, and, secondly, the need for effective solutions.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook, in his answer today, of which we are taking note, said that the whole problem we now have is due to capital goods imports and the drought. He called it simply a transitional and climatic problem. I do not know what Senator Cook's definition of a transitional problem is, but we have a problem today of the same magnitude in terms of the proportion of the economy involved as the one we had in May 1986, when the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, said that if we continued on the road we were on, we would become a banana republic. That had a very striking impact on Australians, because it did bring home the magnitude of the problem. That problem was largely caused by then Treasurer Keating's own economic policies in the preceding two or three years. But he did draw attention to that fact. It was reasonable that average Australians like me would expect the government to do something to solve that problem on a long-term structural basis.

Today we have Senator Cook, Senator Evans, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Treasurer Willis carrying on like this. They say that all the structural changes have been put in place, that we now have a transitional problem and that, after that, everything will be rosy. We heard all of that in 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989 and 1990, when we had the recession that we had to have to put these structural changes in place. Simply nothing has happened other than a deterioration of the position in the last few years after an admittedly small improvement in the balance of payments situation in the late 1980s and very early 1990s as a result of the worst recession that we have had since the Depression.

That recession should never have occurred. It was not a recession that we had to have. It was a recession we had because of the incompetence and policy failures of the Keating-Hawke government before then.

As a result of all that, we have seen our debt escalate to $180,000 million per year. The cost of interest on that debt last year was $22,000 million. It will be of the same magnitude in the year that we are just completing. Depending on international interest rates, it will be even higher next year. There will probably be higher interest rates on a higher level of debt.

The government is saying that the budget that has been brought in is designed to tackle our fundamental problem, which it has described as a long-term savings problem. I agree with that. The one small problem with that is that the budget does nothing to solve our long-term savings problem. Indeed, it exacerbates the problem. The government says that this budget will be accompanied by a balance of payments deficit in the next financial year, 1995-96, of exactly the same magnitude as this year, which is an all time record and, on the government's own description, if one believes the 1986 description, will lead to a banana republic situation. The complacency that has been shown here today by Senator Cook and Senator Evans is a matter of very great concern. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
