SPEECH.PARA: We have had discussions with industry on this and they presented their figures based on their methodology. We made our calculations based on our methodology and we stick by them.
If that is the case, I ask Senator Cook to table the relevant documents in here.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook suggested that a line of questioning to elicit that information could be adopted at the senate estimates committee. Why is he not prepared to give that information in the senior chamber, here in the Senate? I can assure him that Senator Short and I would certainly take up that challenge and we will ask the Treasury officials for much more information in that regard.

This sales tax slug of 12 per cent will have a very dramatic effect throughout Australia. In every area of home building, in every area of renovation, in every area of office construction it will have a pass-on effect.

The government has been crowing about the changes this budget makes in the area of superannuation—changes to compensate for its walking away from its promised tax cuts—but those changes do nothing to help any self-funded retiree. Similarly, this 12 per cent slug on building materials will have a major effect on self-funded retirees because many of those people rely on improvements or changes to their housing and domestic status. So there is a straight 12 per cent tax that will affect all aged people who chose to change their housing status at the important point of their retirement. Yet the government will not come clean and release the methodology of its calculations and recognise the consequences these measures will have on the housing industry and all Australian families. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney this day, relating to small business.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet again it is very disappointing to see the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) wash his hands of this matter and try to pretend that it is a state and federal issue. This is exactly what the minister did at the small business rally in Newcastle and he received a very hot reception from those attending for what seemed to them to be his total lack of interest in doing anything at the federal level.

PARA.TAB: Everyone knows that it is a complex area where state laws, local laws and federal laws have some effect on what happens in the competitive position of small business. However, this federal minister has consistently—and I remind the Senate that this government has been in power for 12 years and we have had more liberal trading laws for the last eight of those years—sat on his hands and done nothing to help the competitive position of small business.
At the start of the rally the minister was crowing that he came to Newcastle to speak to people and gave the impression that he did it of his own volition. That was not true at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —With a gun at his head.

—With a gun at his head, as Senator Panizza points out. The truth is that it was only because the shadow Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Mrs Moylan, was coming to speak to the group that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) told the minister to change his arrangements and make sure that he went to Newcastle. He did that, and he received a razz—as did the lord mayor for his part in this matter. In response to a dorothy dix from his own side, the minister admitted that the only thing the federal government has done to help small business is set up a working party. Is that not great? Small business people are going broke at the rate of one a day, and what does the minister do? He sets up a working party!

PARA.TAB: The minister claims that he has been around listening to small businessmen; he even claimed that he had been to 400 meetings of small businessmen. George, one of the fruiterers at the meeting, said, `You have been to 400 meetings and still you know nothing'. That sums up the fact that this minister has not responded to the real concerns of small business.

A measure of the crisis of small business in the Hunter region—and probably elsewhere—is that one small business a day is closing as a result of the government's lack of action. It was best summed up by a notice outside a fruit shop in Newcastle last week. The notice said this: `Customers, we are closing down today. Reason: 24 hour trading and price wars between supermarkets have halved our turnover and we are losing money every week. What choice do we have? Twelve more on the dole'.

I went to another fruit shop at Merewether. This person is still in business with a staff of 14. He is losing money, but he supplies the naval ships that come to the port and that cross-subsidises his fruit shop. His 14 staff will go on the dole if nothing changes. If this government understands nothing else, it should understand that because of its policies and because of this do nothing minister, who washes his hands at the federal level, more people will be on the dole and we will have a bigger unemployment problem than we have at the moment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 17 May 1995, of former Senator Arthur Ray Devlin, senator for the state of Tasmania from 1984 until 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday, 17 May 1995, of Arthur Ray Devlin, a Senator for the state of Tasmania from 1984 to 1990, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy President, Ray Devlin was born in Burnie, Tasmania, on 17 March 1926. Starting his working life early, he left school at the age of 14 to take a job at Rosebery, where he worked as a miner for 4 1/2 years.

PARA.TAB: After gaining membership of the Waterside Workers Federation, Ray began his lifelong work on the Burnie waterfront, where he was employed for some 34 years until his election to the Senate in late 1984. Ray was always proud of the fact that he had come to parliament with many years experience as a working man and as a member of the trade union movement. He was a life member of the Waterside Workers Federation, and his commitment to the union movement was manifested by his 27-year stint as Secretary of the Burnie Trades and Labour Council.

Ray Devlin committed himself to representing the views of the ordinary working man and woman throughout his parliamentary career. In his maiden speech, he referred to the importance of the union movement in winning better conditions for the working man but working to resist changes which might run counter to the best interests of the worker. He had first-hand experience of the detrimental effect the technological revolution could have on employment. His speech touched on the other issues that most concerned him and which he felt warranted pursuit from his new position. Not surprisingly, these included industrial relations and the role of government in the pursuit of social justice and equity.

Ray's approach to issues was always from the perspective of the individual. He never forgot, as he used to put it, `that behind statistics lie people like us'. At the start of his parliamentary career, his hope was that this idealism of a kind expressed by all newly elected senators at the time would not be short lived. In Ray's case, there was no doubt that he remained true to his ideals. He championed workers' rights and he held firm to his belief in the principles of unionism.

During his time here, Ray was a tireless committee worker. He served five years on the Library Committee and the Publications Committee and on the Select Committee on Animal Welfare, completing its inquiry as Chairman, and the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, among others. He also served on the joint committees on the Australian Capital Territory and the new Parliament House.

Ray Devlin, as I remember him and as others here will, was a friendly and decent character who was as much respected by his colleagues as he was by the general work force in Parliament House. He became known as the unofficial Parliament House shop steward for championing the cause of the workers that kept this place going—so much so that, when he retired in 1990, he was presented with a gift from the Senate staff. Notwithstanding the relatively short period of his service as a senator—Ray Devlin was with us right through the latter eighties, from 1984 to 1990—he will be remembered fondly by all of us with whom he worked. On behalf of the government, I extend to his wife Vurlie—who was a great support for Ray and who was a very familiar face around the parliament—and his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of coalition senators to support this motion of condolence on the death of our former colleague Senator Ray Devlin. Senator Devlin had a long history within the Labor movement, being an active trade unionist for some 55 years. He came into the Senate in 1984, having risen through the ranks of the Waterside Workers Federation and served as Secretary of the Burnie Trades and Labour Council—a position he filled until as recently as 1993. I note that not only was Ray an accomplished runner and footballer but also he rated as a good amateur boxer. The fact that he was a boxing instructor with the Police and Citizens Club tells us something about Ray and his willingness to contribute to the community, particularly to young people.

PARA.TAB: During his time in the Senate, as was said by Senator Gareth Evans, until his retirement in 1990 he served on many committees, including his time as Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I want to mention his interest in and contribution to industrial relations matters within the parliament. Clearly his interest from his background did not diminish when he entered this place. I remember Ray going in to bat for the cleaning staff on one occasion. That is a record which I would commend.

I wish to make one further point. Others who were closer to Ray will no doubt speak further of personal matters. In both his first and his last speech in this place, he paid a warm and glowing tribute to his wife Vurlie. These tributes, I suggest, highlight the often unheralded sacrifices and contributions made by spouses and partners of senators. On behalf of coalition senators, I express condolences to his wife and family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate National Party senators with the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). I was very saddened to hear of the death of our friend and former colleague, Ray Devlin, who passed away so soon after his retirement from the political system.

PARA.TAB: I got to know Ray fairly well. He was proud to be called a worker. I said in the Senate a number of times that Ray Devlin was one of the real working men. He was truly representative of the working class people. It was his proudest boast in the Senate that he was a working man and he represented the working people of Tasmania.

He worked in the mines and the post office, and on the waterfront for a number of years. He then had six years in the Senate. I imagine he would have been very proud to have come from a humble beginning and to have found his way into the Senate. It is only to be welcomed that a person such as Ray Devlin can represent his people in a chamber such as this where there are all types of people. We have economists, solicitors, merchants and people across the whole economic spectrum.

Ray Devlin and I were on the ATSIC committee together. We went around Australia and up into the Torres Strait. I think Senator McMullan was the chairman of that committee at the time. We took evidence from a number of Aboriginal communities. When you are on a Senate committee and move into outback areas with people from different sides of politics, you get to know them very well. I found Ray to be a delightful person who made a contribution in many ways. He was rewarded for that contribution by a place in the Senate. I wish his family well. I know we would all say he was a good working man.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate the Australian Democrats with this condolence motion. I knew Ray Devlin for only a short time. I met him when I first came to this place. For a few months I served with him on the animal welfare committee. Before arriving here I had heard of his influence in and contributions to this place. As a Tasmanian, I respected the contribution he had made. I had not been on the animal welfare committee for long before I was able to recognise his genuine interest in and concern for the welfare of animals. Although it was not a long time that we shared a space on that committee, I soon detected his personal fascination with equine welfare in particular. You could always get a lively discussion from Ray if the conversation turned to horses. The argument was not always resolved with the running of the last race. There was always something else to be added.

PARA.TAB: Actually, that was an aspect of the man that attracted me to him because he did share with my grandfather this fascination with this particular aspect of our sporting and entertainment industries. He also shared a background with my grandfather on the north-west Tasmanian waterfront and I found it fascinating to speak with him about those two aspects.

It is a traditional Australian Labor Party background. He was a person who was effective if not always as forceful as some are in expressing his opinions from that background; and he spoke plainly, with a voice which did reflect his values and the values and aspirations of so many people from that part of Tasmania. As such, he was an effective advocate on their behalf and I think he should be admired for that and it is that that I will remember about him.

We will miss people of Ray's calibre and, in particular, his style. But if we remind ourselves of the things that he believed were important, then I believe we will be much more effective as a chamber, because it is the memory of people such as Ray Devlin that give the sort of power and authority to the decisions we make. However, if we forget them, then we should be ashamed of ourselves.

I will certainly make an effort to remember the style and the aspirations that were contained in Ray Devlin. I think we are the sadder for his departing. I pass on the Australian Democrats' condolences to his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray Devlin made a remarkable contribution to his community, to his state and to his country. Throughout his life he strove mightily to improve the wellbeing of all three.

PARA.TAB: Ray worked through the union movement to achieve much of his success. He saw that organisation as the ideal vehicle to bring his considerable abilities to the help of the vulnerable and the disadvantaged. A myriad of people owe much to Ray Devlin unionist.

As stated by Senator Boswell and again just now by other senators, Ray was close to blue collar workers and to their families. He grew up amongst them, he laboured with them, he played with them, he rejoiced, grieved and conversed and sat in silence with them. He never moved away from them. He was truly a man of the people.

As Senator Hill stated, Ray was a prominent sportsman. When he was in the Senate, you will remember, Mr President, he looked fit and he was fit. The injury he suffered to his leg earlier in life impaired an otherwise sound body. Ray experienced those ills of life common to us all. He met them with uncommon courage. The way he faced his death is conclusive evidence of this.

He was a man of integrity, a man of unfailing commitment to those he served, a man of courage. Vurlie was the ideal companion for Ray. Her loss is great and we sympathise with her, but she will show the spirit of Ray Devlin and that will see her through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ray Devlin came into the Senate 15 months before I came as a senator for Tasmania to join him and we served together as colleagues for about four years.

PARA.TAB: I liked Ray Devlin. He was a decent man. I liked the fact that he had such warmth and togetherness with his wife Vurlie. He and I had a good personal relationship which is not always the thing in political terms across the party boundaries, but I think the essential decency of the man showed through so that any relationships with him were good ones.

One of the nice things too about Ray Devlin was that being a senator did not change him. He was still the Ray Devlin that had been a waterside worker, that had been a secretary of the Burnie Trades and Labour Council and that had been, as he very proudly was, a boxing instructor for the police and citizens club. He was a battler too, he understood battlers and he represented battlers.

To my mind he was very much the old-style Labor man. He understood the traditional Labor voter and I wonder sometimes whether he felt a little bit lost on the back benches opposite, where the Labor Party seemed to have gone on to other things and there were not too many of the old style Labor men left to be colleagues to Ray Devlin.

I know the Senate staff, the older ones who served at the time that Ray was here, will be sad at his loss because he was a true friend to them. I know that they will miss him, as I do. I say to his wife, Vurlie, and to his family how sorry we are to learn of his death. Cancer is not an easy death anyway, but the death of any loved one is hard to cope with. I send them my very best wishes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with this condolence motion. I sat next to Ray Devlin while he was in the Senate. He was my mate. I think that he really epitomised a phenomenon in Australia of regional trade unionism. That is what he was, as secretary to the Trades and Labour Council at Burnie. Throughout his life, Ray contributed to the community of Burnie, and beyond it. He brought the community's concerns into the parliament. I think that his being so close to the people was indicated here when he took the same spirit into this chamber and when he worked for oppressed people in this place.

PARA.TAB: I remember the disputes in the dining room, in the transport sections and in the other areas of the old Parliament House about people who might have been disadvantaged. After all, we, the elite, were being looked after as we came from the old Parliament House to this Parliament House, but Ray was concerned about the loyal employees who, in many cases, were perhaps not getting their just desserts as the transition was made. I remember that he would grab me and other people in order to increase the pressure on us to make sure that those people had justice given to them. It was instinctive for him, with that sense of justice, to make sure that people were helped.

I think that in every way he was a proud son of the working class. He took into his life the culture of the working class. Somebody has mentioned horseracing. I remember a bit about greyhounds. On one occasion, he and another senator went to a greyhound race, as the other senator had a greyhound racing here in Canberra. Ray confided that he did not think it would be the best thing for the two senators to wear their coats when they went to this race track where the greyhound was to run. So they at least had the dignity, knowing all the procedures about clothing in this chamber, to take their coats off and go coatless while this greyhound went and won the race against the local competition. I am not certain that they told the local competition that it was a Sydney greyhound that was running that day against the Canberra greyhounds.

With his strong culture of the working class and his interest in those sporting activities, Ray's consistency in being with the people followed through. To Vurlie, his wife, who was inseparable from him, I pass on my best wishes at this terrible hour for her. I always remember the work that she put into the Emu Bay recipe book, at an Emu Bay branch of the Labor Party. That became quite famous as all the celebrities around this place made their contributions to it. It was typical of that couple to work together. They raised their money in the simplest of ways to support their local campaigns. It is with great sadness that I associate myself with this condolence motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the remarks of my colleagues on the sad passing of Ray Devlin. Ray was one of the first people I met when I came into parliament. Barney Cooney, Warwick Parer, Michael Baume and I all shared a corridor with Ray in the old Parliament House, just up from the Senate transport office. That office was one in which Ray Devlin spent a fair bit of time because he and the transport officer at the time shared a love of racing. Everyone has mentioned the racing. I think Ray Devlin had more tips than anyone could have ever had. He never gave me any tips, but I am sure he was quite a successful punter. Ray was one of life's genuine people. He came to the Senate with few pretensions, and I believe that he left with few.

PARA.TAB: I worked with Ray on the Senate animal welfare committee. At one time he was its chairman. As Senator Gareth Evans said, he was a keen worker—whether it was looking at the broiler industry or the laying hen industry, which were two of the major inquiries we had at the time. He played a major part in those inquiries which, of course, led on to racing afterwards.

The one aspect of his Senate life that he did not like was that it took him away from his home and his beloved wife, Vurlie, who frequently travelled to Canberra to be with him. I extend my sympathies to Vurlie and family. He was a true representative of the people and one of nature's true gentlemen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to the late Ray Devlin, senator for Tasmania between 1984 and 1990. Ray devoted his life to the working people of Tasmania in his role as a workplace union delegate for the waterside workers in Burnie, as secretary for the Burnie branch of the Trades and Labour Council and later as a senator. I served with Ray on various committees within the Labor Party in Tasmania for over a decade. I know from those experiences that Ray was tough and uncompromising in his principles but was always fair. He knew in his own mind the minimum standards he would accept and he always tried to transpose those standards to the people he represented. Life's path often takes one along a route that one would never have envisaged. Ray Devlin made this statement in his first speech. He never imagined that, as a worker in a mine at 14, he would end up representing his state in the Senate—and he was very proud of that achievement.

PARA.TAB: On completing his term in the Senate, Ray continued his work to ensure employment opportunities were maximised in Tasmania. When a saw mill was struggling to survive, Ray, together with a committee from the Burnie branch of the Trades and Labour Council, stepped in and assisted. He used his contacts to seek orders for sawn timber and sell the residue in the form of woodchips. The mill would not have survived without his intervention. Today that mill still survives, employing 20 people. That is a credit to Ray. Ray Devlin will be sadly missed by those who knew and loved him. I offer my deepest sympathy to his devoted wife Vurlie, and to Michael, Vicky and Tony, together with their families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate myself, too, with this condolence motion. I first met and got to know Ray before I became a senator. My association with the late Senator Devlin goes back to when I was President of the Royal Agricultural Society in Tasmania. We used to have a few problems with the Showman's Guild in those days and that is when I first got to know Ray Devlin. Through mutual friends that we acquired over the years in the Showman's Guild, I became quite close to Ray.

PARA.TAB: In this place you become closer to some members and senators than to others. Ray was one of my closer friends, so I was very sad not to have been able to see Ray before he passed away. I made a couple of attempts but, unfortunately, in recent times I had other things on my mind when I travelled to the north-west coast and I seemed to run out of time.

I am well aware of the great mateship, friendship and love that he and Vurlie had for each other. If we look at Ray's valedictory, we see it all summed up when he said, `On a personal note I must pay tribute to the tireless and unselfish support given to me by my wife, Vurlie.' I think he played down the role Vurlie played in his life. She was a great companion and a great mate to him the whole time he was here.

He was a very proud No. 1 badge holder of the Showman's Guild of Tasmania. He made many friends not just in Tasmania but right throughout Australia because of that association. I remember working with him on more than one occasion to try to calm down the sorts of problems that arose between the Showman's Guild and agricultural shows not just in Tasmania but all the way up the eastern seaboard. He was very good at that.

Mention was made of his chairmanship of the animal welfare committee. I do not think anybody was ever prouder than Ray Devlin the day that he, other members of the committee and I marched on to Flemington race track on Melbourne Cup Day. We started at track work at 4 o'clock in the morning. We were still working at 4 o'clock that afternoon. Even though we were accused in the media of being on a bit of a junket, we realised—Ray, in particular—that in the course of that inquiry we had to see the hardest and best race in the world if we were going to put down a complete report. Unfortunately the report did not go into as much detail as Ray would have liked. If he had his time over again, I am sure he would have concentrated on more aspects of the horse racing industry. As has been said, he was very concerned about the industry and what was happening to it.

I know he formed a very close relationship with former Senator Brian Archer. I am sure that if Brian had been here today he would have said some very complimentary things about Ray Devlin. Although they were on completely different sides of the fence, they worked very closely together for the people of the north-west coast. After Ray's retirement he used Brian Archer's office on many occasions to do what he did best—to look after and work for what he called the average battler.
I pass on my condolences to Vurlie and their family. I hope that I can catch up with her and express my sympathy to her personally.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I first met Ray Devlin in the mid-1970s. He was always very active in the Australian Labor Party and in the trade union movement. I did not really get to know Ray until 1979, when I became secretary of what was then the Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union. Ray had represented our union on the north-west coast without pay. He represented our union on the north-west coast because we had no full-time union official in that area. He was very dedicated and committed to the rights of workers across the industrial spectrum. I particularly noticed this in the work he performed for our organisation.

PARA.TAB: There were many individuals on many occasions who, if it had not been for Ray Devlin, would not have obtained redress—getting their employment back or back wages—for being poorly treated in the hospitality industry, of which I had first-hand experience. He was always a committed trade unionist and a committed worker, as all speakers today have noted. He never lost those values. He never changed those basic principles or that outlook on life.

I got to know Ray much better when I moved to the north-west coast some six years ago. Particularly in the last two years when I had my home and office in Burnie, Ray and Vurlie would often come down and have a cup of tea. We talked primarily about two issues. I had been painting my home for the last two years. Ray was very good at giving me tips about how to do the work. I did not realise until the last few weeks prior to his death that Ray had actually been an apprentice painter. That was one of the very diverse occupations he had during his working life. The other issue which we would talk about was a pretty hot issue for Tasmania—forestry. I will not go into it in detail now. Ray and I would often talk about forest related matters.

The way Ray coped over the last couple of months, when it became apparent that he did not have much longer to live, is a tribute to the courage of the man. He really did suffer enormously in the last couple of months. It was quite heart rending to see him when I visited him on a number of occasions. You could see the tremendous pain and the difficulty he was going through during that time. Through and despite the enormous pain, he always had a laugh, a smile and a story to tell. He fought right up to the last few hours of his life.
Vurlie looked after him not just in the last few weeks but for all their married life. He could not have had a more committed or dedicated partner in life.

There are a couple of other points about Ray. Few of us who leave this place are given a party by the staff—the drivers and the attendants. A mark of the respect, dedication and friendship that the staff in this place had for Ray Devlin was displayed when they remembered him when he retired.

He cared for the working men and women of this country. He devoted his entire life to that cause in his own way. He never forgot where he came from or the struggle of the 1930s and the 1940s, which was a very difficult period.
I express my sympathy to Vurlie and to Ray's children. He will not be forgotten.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to join with those colleagues who have risen in this condolence debate to pay a tribute to Ray Devlin, the former senator—the man, the husband and the father. I first got to know Ray when he came to this place. He, Senator Cooney and I were elected on the same day. We arrived at this place as rank novices, not knowing where to go or what to do. The three of us got rooms in what became somewhat infamously known as the Senate side of the chamber. There we formed a very close bond of friendship, not only between us as individual members of parliament but also between our spouses.

PARA.TAB: Vurlie continued to work with him, as she had done throughout their married life. She was in his office, constantly looking after him—not only looking after him but also those of his mates around him. I am proud to stand here and record the fact that he saw me as a mate of his and that I, in turn, saw him as a mate of mine. I say that in the nicest Australian way in which mateship is formed in this country.

I knew he was a strong individual; he had to be strong to have survived the rigours of the life which he had led. It is on the record of this place that he started work at a very young age. He changed his age in order to be allowed to work legally under ground in the mines in Tasmania. That required courage. He certainly showed that courage very early in his life. It was also courageous to be associated from time to time with the trade union movement in this country. Ray never hid his light under a bushel when it came to saying where he came from or where he was. He continued to associate with the trade union movement. When he was a senator he did not feel that he had left the trade union movement, particularly the organisation he loved most of all—the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. He continued to work for that association.

Mention has been made of the fact that after he left this place he continued to work for the Burnie Trades and Labour Council. It was only a couple of years ago, as Senator Murphy will recall, that that organisation put on a retirement function for him. It was in Burnie in 1993. I had the pleasure of attending and renewing the friendship and acquaintance not only with Ray but also with his wife, Vurlie.

Great sympathy has to be directed to Vurlie. She and Ray were very close, much closer than most of the people and their partners that are involved in this political game. When he became sick it was a strength to him and to her that their love was so strong. The second last time I spoke to the man I was amazed how strong he was. He had just left hospital. He had been diagnosed as having terminal cancer. He knew his end was coming. We all address ourselves as to how we will react when we get that news. He decided to take charge of things for himself and his family.

I spoke to him only a day after he left hospital. He was arranging a meeting for later in the week with the whole family. He knew they were going to suffer in the coming days and weeks and he was going to try and make it as easy as possible for them. That shows a strength of character and I hope that when my time comes I can be as strong as Ray Devlin was. I spoke to him again when I was overseas and that meeting with his family had taken place. He figured he had done whatever he could to prepare his family for the inevitability that was going to strike them. I think that says much about Ray Devlin, the man.

Much has been said about his work in the Senate. Probably the greatest mark he made in this place was as an advocate for the working people in this place. He stood by the catering staff when they were faced with retrenchment, when they were being paid a pittance. Some of the people working in catering were actually receiving top-up benefits from Social Security. When that was revealed around the place and to their union and to Ray Devlin, he took it on with a passion that only a person from the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia could demonstrate. It was quite a successful campaign.

He did regret, however, that he was not in this place when the parliamentary catering service was privatised. He certainly had strong views on that. Despite the fact that he was no longer in parliament, he was quite willing to share those views with anybody who was prepared to listen and to place on the record what we should be doing in order to protect those workers.

Another body of workers around this place that he was particularly close to was the Comcar drivers. They have also been under some pressures in recent years, and he had strong views as to what should happen in that area. I am sure that, if Ray Devlin had remained in the parliament after June 1990, he would have been making life somewhat difficult for some of the ministers and bureaucrats who are associated with Comcar.

I think that what his colleagues are doing today is not so much weeping over Ray Devlin but rather speaking in joy of the man that they knew. He was a great Australian, a great Tasmanian and a great representative of the working-class people of this country. His record is there, and it is now up to his family to glory in the fact that they are associated with that record.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a fellow Tasmanian, I also want to pay tribute to Ray Devlin. He came into the Senate at the time it was expanded in 1984. As Senator McKiernan said, several of his colleagues at the time were new senators. As everyone has also said already, in the whole time he was here, he did not change from how he was throughout his life.

PARA.TAB: He was a real stalwart of the north-west coast of Tasmania. As long-time secretary of the Burnie Trades and Labour Council, he acted on behalf of not only the waterside workers but also members of various other unions, especially those that otherwise did not have full-time representation in the area. He was very much seen as a central representative of the trade union movement on the north-west coast. That often made him unpopular with some parts of the Burnie community, but I am sure that those whom he really represented fully appreciated that he was working in their interests and he had many victories on their behalf.

Also, as has been mentioned before, he continued that representation in this building by looking after the interests of various staff, championing their cause when they were most in need of support. I am very sorry that circumstances made it impossible for me to get to Burnie for Ray's funeral last week, but I was certainly there in spirit. I pass my condolences to Vurlie, who will miss him deeply.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saddened when I heard of the passing of our former colleague Ray Devlin, and I therefore wish to be associated with the motion of condolence moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. As has already been stated, Ray was a senator from 1984 to 1990. He would have preferred to continue representing Tasmania and would have done so except for an age barrier in his party's rules.

PARA.TAB: I did not know Ray before he entered the Senate. After hearing details of his life at his funeral service last week, I wish I had known him prior to his entry to this place. He certainly had a rich and varied career, right from the time he advanced his age by many years so he could be employed underground in a mine.

In the six years that Ray was here, he and I developed a close friendship. Some people whom we meet in life's journey are eminently forgettable; others like Ray are just the opposite. Even though I had not seen him since he left this place in 1990, I could never forget my friendship with Ray and his wife Vurlie.

Some senators will remember that my wife Dawn had a most unfortunate accident in this building only hours before the Senate first met in this chamber. She did not see the first sitting, being instead in the Canberra hospital preparing for surgery due to her accident. Naturally, that day and the immediate days which followed were stressful for my wife, my two sons and for me. Yet, in the midst of our efforts to cope with a quite unexpected event, a magnificent arrangement of flowers arrived for Dawn at the hospital, having been sent by Ray and Vurlie. It was an extremely kind gesture, one that Dawn and I will never forget.

In the pragmatism which pervades this parliament, some of us occasionally bend our principles to achieve a result which is not what we are aiming for but which we can live with. Yet that never happened with Ray. He never strayed from the principles he had developed over the years and brought to this place.

As has already been mentioned, Ray was unashamedly a champion of the worker. Many in this building are aware of his efforts to assist them in times of industrial dispute. He was so highly regarded by members of what I might call the general staff that one of them actually travelled to Tasmania for his funeral service. I recall his anguish when a picket was placed on the entrances to Parliament House during one dispute. He knew he had a responsibility to attend the parliament, but he said to me, `I don't know what to do. I've never crossed a picket line in my life.' Fortunately, senators and members were exempted from crossing the line. Ray was able not only to attend parliament but also to take part in negotiations on behalf of the workers in the parliament building itself.

I was pleased I had the opportunity to attend Ray's funeral service in Burnie last week. When my time comes, I would be greatly pleased if I had as good a send-off as Ray did. St George's Church of England was overflowing with those who came to pay their respects. Of current members of parliament, I remember seeing Senator Murphy and Mr Chris Miles. Also present were three of our former colleagues: George Georges, Brian Archer and Terry Aulich.

As the cortege left the church and began to make its way to the cemetery at Devonport, it was preceded by a piper leading about a hundred of Ray's former union, party and personal friends. Everyone in Burnie knew Ray and, although some did not agree with his political views, he was universally respected.

After the burial service Vurlie said to me, `I will miss him.' There is little one can say to ease that pain, but Vurlie and her family will know that their grief is shared by hundreds upon hundreds who knew Ray. Vurlie can be assured that Ray will not be forgotten because he will live on in our memories. To Vurlie and her family, however, I again express my sincere condolences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to participate in this condolence motion moved by Senator Gareth Evans. I have known Ray and Vurlie Devlin for some period of time and have developed a great deal of respect for both of them. Our association has not always been one in which we agreed. We came from different factions of the party but that never stopped us from being able to get on together. In later years I developed a very good friendship with both Ray and Vurlie. They were great contributors to the party. Vurlie Devlin was probably one of the major fundraisers for the party during the 1980s. Although at times they found difficulty with some decisions at a state level, they never lost sight of the fact that they were Labor people and would always continue to be so.

PARA.TAB: Ray Devlin, as I think Senator Evans said, was the epitome of a working class representative. His working life commenced in the mines in Rosebery at the age of 14. Prior to commencing work there he went to stay with his sister for a holiday after he left school. I do not know whether school was so difficult that he needed a holiday after it but that is where he went. It was suggested by his brother-in-law that he should try to get a job at the mine. Ray went along to do that but you could not start work at the mine, at least above ground, unless you were 18. So he trotted along and said he was 18 but unfortunately he was informed that there were no jobs above ground, although there were jobs underground for which you had to be 19. So Ray went back a few days later and dutifully informed them that he had turned 19. He worked there for another 4 1/2 years and then came back to Burnie, where he became a member of the Waterside Workers Federation. He worked on the waterfront for 33 years and 11 months and participated in many difficult times from an industrial point of view during that period.

He became the secretary of the Burnie Trades and Labour Council, a position which he held for 27 years. He was also one to participate in the community. He was the boxing instructor for the Police and Citizens Boys Club for 17 years—and not without some success, because Ray helped to train nine Tasmanian champions and 14 schoolboy champions, and promoted for the club the professional light and heavyweight championships of Australia, refereed by Arthur Tunstall, a less famous person today than he might have been then. The boxer trained by Ray won the title, which attracted some funds for the club.

Ray always sought to help people throughout his life, right until the day he died. There are a few stories which I would like to tell relating to Ray's experiences when he was secretary of the Burnie Trades and Labour Council. These stories do not relate to industrial disputes, they relate to people within the community who Ray helped.

One was a woman who had purchased a second-hand car from a well-known car dealer on the north-west coast. Not long after taking delivery of the car, it broke down. Ray came to hear about this. He sought her out and they had a talk about it. The car dealer was, and still remains, quite well known for some infamous slogans that he uses to sell cars. At that time he had one called `war on prices—WOP'.

After hearing the woman's story about the circumstances in which she found herself, with little money and a broken down car of which she had just taken delivery, Ray went to see the car dealer. Ray said, `It's WOP, war on prices. If we don't fix this thing up, there is another definition of WOP and you're likely to find out about it.' Of course, following that discussion, the woman was given another car by the car dealer. In fact, it was probably better than the one she started out with.

That became a bit of a story in the local community. Another woman heard about that story. She somehow took a car on trial. She went to Ray and said, `I had to pay this car dealer a $500 deposit. I took this car on trial to see if it was any good. They came and took the car back when I said it was no good but they won't give me my $500 back.' Ray said, `We'll have to sort that out for you.' He sought to make some inquiries. He had a meeting with the Burnie Trades and Labour Council executive. Two of the officers, Norm Britton and Ray Grundy, were given the task of getting further information about the woman and the $500 that had been paid. Ray said, `I'll go and see the car dealer, we'll soften him up and see if we can sort this out.' Following that discussion with the car dealer there was another meeting at the Trades and Labour Council at which Ray was informed by Norm Britton and Ray Grundy that the girl had never paid a $500 deposit. So some apologies and a working out of that issue had to be taken up with the car dealer.

The efforts which Ray put into the Burnie community were ultimately recognised. In 1990 the Burnie City Council awarded Ray a certificate of merit for his efforts and for his services to the community. From an industrial point of view, of course, there would not have been a dispute on the north-west coast or, indeed, probably in Tasmania, in which Ray Devlin was not involved in some form or another.

I know from my own experience with the APPM dispute that Ray's knowledge and association with the police in particular were very handy. His communication skills at that level were invaluable during that dispute. His services to the trade union movement have also been recognised by the fact that he was made a life member of the Waterside Workers Federation, which is now the MUA. He was made a life member of the Transport Workers Union, the FEDFA, the painters and decorators and the CFMEU. He was a life member and No. 1 ticket holder of the Showmen's Guild. As I understand it, they are not going to award that to anyone else.

As I said, Ray continued to pursue the interests of people who needed assistance right until the day he died; so much so that even when Ray was in hospital he used to ring me about a particular issue relating to forestry. He was representing a person who was seeking a woodchip licence. We used to talk about how we were going to achieve that. I talked to Ray just days before he died. He had wished that we could resolve this issue before he died. Unfortunately, we could not.

Ray has left behind a family, including Vurlie. Vurlie had two children from a previous marriage and Ray had a son, Michael, from a previous marriage. Ray ended up with eight or nine grandchildren, all of whom he loved dearly. They were a great source of joy to him. I guess that a lot of people never understood properly or always underestimated Ray Devlin's contribution to the community. Vurlie has asked that I thank all senators for their kind wishes and their support during this time. Can I just say that, for Ray Devlin, I hope the struggle continues, as it will for me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was in 1966 or 1967 that Ray Devlin was catapulted into the union office as a result of the tragic death of two prominent north-west coast unionists at the time. I have known Ray Devlin since the early 1960s because I too had an association with the Burnie waterfront in respect of negotiations on wages and working conditions of a number of people there—tallyclerks and the like. There were times when disagreements arose with Ray and the executive of the BTLC when I was elected Secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council. The rules of the ACTU required the TTLC—the state branch of the ACTU—to uphold the rules of the ACTU for the conduct and control of industrial disputes. I had been urged to insist upon those rules by a number of organisations and affiliated unions; I am not going to mention them here. They had just cause to require me to do that. That led to a difference of viewpoint.

PARA.TAB: I was able to cooperate with Ray in his position as an official of the WWF and with many WWF members in Tasmania and nationally. Following that period—more particularly, over the last 10 years and in the time that Ray was a member of the Senate—I realised that we shared the fundamental principles of labour. He and I were concerned that the philosophy—if you like to use that elevated term—of economic rationalism was influencing decisions far too much in a government which we both felt ought to be motivated by the principles of labour, which we both shared.

Ray Devlin's forte was that he had time for others. He quietly and effectively worked for battlers. His forte was not speeches in this place. He was a member of a number of Senate committees, as honourable senators know. When Stephen Loosley's farewell speeches were made in this place there was a recognition of the fact that Stephen Loosley defended the indefensible. He came in here plenty of times to defend government policy but within the committee milieu was able to listen to other points of view and use his influence to effect an outcome which often did not flow from preconceived policies. So it was with Ray Devlin. On committees he quite frequently came forward with some views and supported others which were based not on preconceived ideas but on the evidence that was put before the committees. That is something that is important for this chamber. He then assisted this chamber in exercising that role.

I was sorry that I was not able to be present at Ray Devlin's funeral; I was at young Shane Morrisby's funeral in Hobart. I would like to associate myself very much with this motion of condolence to Vurlie and to Ray's family.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—The President has received a letter from Senator Campbell proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

Mr Keating's failure to appreciate that the success of small business is critical to the social and economic well-being of all Australians as demonstrated by his arrogant remarks and high taxing budget.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of this matter of public importance, as set out in my letter to the President, spring from personal experiences that I have had in the last couple of weeks and over the last couple of months, often in meeting small business people. To a man and woman, they would be absolutely disgusted by the comments that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, made in a series of post-budget media appearances as he went from town to town, city to city and radio studio to radio studio to sell his so-called budget.

PARA.TAB: Those of us on this side of the chamber who have witnessed the results of Mr Keating going from radio station to radio station to sell the so-called budget would encourage him to do more of it. The more he goes around, the more people will understand that the budget was not a budget. The closest the budget comes to being any sort of credible financial document is when we compare it with the forecasts and predictions in the prospectuses of groups like Qintex, the Bond Corporation and Rothwells merchant bank in the late 1980s. The underlying assumptions in the budget have about as much credibility as the forecasts in those more interesting documents.
The Prime Minister said of small business people:

SPEECH.PARA: If they are feeling the pinch, they ought to say, `Small business is not for me', because it is never going to get any better. This is as good as it ever gets. So, if they are feeling the pinch, they have got to say, `I had better go back to PAYE employment.'

I have spoken to a lot of small business people—mostly in my home town of Perth—since the Prime Minister made that comment and they are disgusted. This matter of public importance relates to the Prime Minister's incredible arrogance in making remarks that show him to be very much out of touch with reality and with the important role of the small business sector. I am very pleased to see the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) in the chamber because I know that he understands that importance. I hope that he will explain it to his Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I want to note some statistics that would be well known to the minister. They bear repeating because the Prime Minister needs reminding of what small business people contribute to this nation, not only to our social and economic wellbeing of Australia, but to the employment situation. They are the heart and soul of our private sector and provide an incredible range of services to our community. They provide employment and security for thousands of families. They are great employment generators and great potential employment generators in an expanding nation.

Presently, there are 865,636 small businesses in Australia. That number probably changes by a couple of hundred every day as new businesses start up and old ones die. Of all businesses in Australia, 96 per cent are classified as small business. They provide 55 per cent of total employment within the private sector. They contribute something in the order of 43 per cent of our gross domestic product. There are more employees in that sector than there are total enrolments in the trade union movement. Even before the budget, this sector paid more in taxes into Commonwealth revenue than did all of big business put together. Small business is the engine room of the economy. It is the innovator in the economy, the first to pick up and promote new ideas. It is very important to future employment.

It is crucial to analyse the words of the Prime Minister when he says that this is as good as it ever gets. I put it to the Prime Minister and to the minister that if small business is faced with that reality, as the Prime Minister sees it, we are all—not just small business people—in very serious trouble. Young people are suffering an enormous unemployment problem. In excess of 312,000 people under 24 do not have jobs. Over 74,000 young people have not had a job for a year. The small business sector can make an enormous contribution if it is allowed to expand and succeed. If this is as good as it ever gets for small business, it is not good enough. Things must get a hell of a lot better for small business if the young people who are looking for jobs are to find those jobs and if we are to solve some of the significant economic, social and cultural problems that we face as a nation.

There is a number of economic indicators that would lead our small business people to agree with my proposition that this is not as good as it gets. For example, we are told that we have low interest rates. Real interest rates—roughly speaking, when you take the inflation rate away from our prime bank rates or interest rates—are among the highest real interest rates in the world. The Economist's latest survey shows that only Canada has higher real interest rates. So our business people are paying nearly the highest real interest rates in the Western world. For them, it is not as good as it should get; it is not as good as it ever gets.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that you mix with people from small business and you would understand that, when small business seeks to expand and find new opportunities for the partners and the employees, costs such as interest rates and taxation make it very difficult for them. We have to ask whether the Prime Minister is correct when he says that this is as good as it ever gets. We have to look at inflation. If we turn to page 118 of the 13 May edition of the Economist we find that Australia has the third highest consumer price index amongst the OECD nations. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, will come in here and tell us that we have a low inflation economy. I guess we have lower inflation than we had during the 1970s and the 1980s, but in comparison with our trade competitors and in terms of relativities Australia has the third highest inflation rate in the Western world. I refer the minister to page 118 of the Economist.

The band of economic forecasters who write for the Economist predict that next year Australia is going to be amongst the highest inflation rate nations in the world. That is very, very hard for small business. It is particularly hard on those who seek to create some savings and invest those savings in the future expansion of their businesses. Only two other budgets have contained larger tax slugs on small business: the Keating budget of 1984 and the Whitlam budget of 1974. Small business is already predicting reductions in sales. According to all the surveys conducted by the various chambers of commerce, small business will be reducing the number of employees being put on their payrolls in the next 12 months. This budget has done nothing to improve the outlook for small business. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —As Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction I rise to speak on behalf of the government on this matter of public importance proposed by Senator Campbell. In the last three or four weeks we have seen a bit of a flurry from those on the other side about their interest in small business. That is welcome because it has been a long time since any Liberal senator has shown any interest in speaking on small business.

PARA.TAB: It has been a very negative thrust; trying to exaggerate the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and use them to show that he does not care about small business. I would like to see Liberal Party senators get up and explain exactly their specific policies for small business. There was not the slightest illumination from Senator Campbell, an opposition front bencher, about what the opposition would do for small business if it wins government. There was no specific policy.

This is where we have the so-called policy-free zone of the Liberal Party. It does not want to announce policies in any area at all. Despite the fact that Mr Howard, the new Leader of the Opposition, has said that he is interested in small business policy and attracting the support of the small business community, he is yet to announce any policy—other than some vague reference to industrial relations that may or may not affect small business. We are still waiting.

I have been to a number of forums. Only two weeks ago I was at a forum in Newcastle in the Hunter valley. Senator Tierney referred to that forum today in question time. He was there. Ms Judi Moylan, the shadow minister for small business, was also there. She made an impassioned speech about her interest in small business; how she had come from the small business sector. But we all waited to hear what the Liberal Party would do for small business that was different from what the government was doing. There was not one word—not one mention.

I do not know how long the Liberal Party believes that it can go on saying, `Elect us, but we do not want to tell you what the policies are and why we ought to be elected to government.' Sooner rather than later, the Liberal Party is going to be in considerable difficulty with its credit in the electorate. This is the real issue in this debate today and in other debates in recent times.

We hear vitriolic attacks on the Prime Minister at a personal level, completely exaggerating and taking his remarks out of context. His remarks were very simple. When we have five per cent growth, as we had in 1994, and two per cent inflation—unheard of figures in Australia's economic history over the last 30 or 40 years—people have the opportunity to do well in business. The Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions subsequently that he was not attacking small business.

I was with him at a business function in Adelaide 2 1/2 weeks ago when he made it very clear that he supported and understood the contribution of small business. Those opposite who want to attack the Prime Minister should remember that his own father ran a very successful small business. He comes from a family environment where he has knowledge of small business. All this rhetoric, abusing the Prime Minister and claiming that he does not understand small business, is not right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does he keep taxing them so highly?

—Senator Campbell interjects on tax. When his party was last in government the corporate tax rate was 46c in the dollar. Even with the recent 3c in the dollar increase it is now only 36c in the dollar. A further thing I want to point out to Senator Campbell is that over half of the 800,000-odd small businesses in Australia are not incorporated and therefore do not pay the corporate tax.
—Half of them are, though.

—Well under half of them are incorporated and therefore pay the corporate tax. When the opposition was last in government it was charging them 46c in the dollar. We are now charging them 36c in the dollar. That is a 10c difference. I know it is embarrassing to the Liberal Party to have it consistently pointed out that it was a much higher taxing party on small business when it was last in office.
—That is simply not true.
—The facts speak for themselves—46c in the dollar compared with 36c in the dollar.
—Pull out the FBT. Pull out all the other taxes, including the WST.
—Even with all the other changes, we pay less in tax in Australia now than when the Liberal Party was last in government. We are the second lowest taxing country in the OECD.
—Not on small business, you aren't.

—On small business we are. We have given more concessions in the small business area than the Liberal Party ever thought of when it was in government. The opposition has not talked about any particular policy. One of the most astonishing things is that at the meeting in the Hunter Valley Ms Moylan read out a letter from the Leader of the Opposition saying, `We will oppose every increase in tax in this budget. We will oppose them in this chamber and elsewhere. We will not vote for any of them.' This was read out to, obviously, some cheers from people present. I had to get up and point out that only two days before that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Costello, when addressing the National Press Club, said that if the opposition was elected to government next year it would not repeal any of those tax increases. Talk about rank hypocrisy! We have the opposition putting out a letter to several hundred thousand small businesses, beating its chest and saying, `We will oppose every one of these tax measures,' and then having to admit—in a different forum, of course, at the National Press Club—that once in government it would never repeal any of those tax measures that those opposite so vehemently oppose here. That is another side of the hypocrisy of the opposition: trying to play off different views and say one thing to one audience and something else to another audience.

PARA.TAB: There were quite a few dismayed looks among the small business community present when they found out the hypocrisy displayed by the Liberal Party in the letter from Mr Howard compared with the remarks by Mr Costello at the National Press Club. Let us deal with the remarks of the Prime Minister and his support for small business. The business community, big and small, leading up to the last budget insisted only one issue had to be dealt with above all others: get interest rates stable or get them down and have no more interest rate increases on the business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a promise?

—That is what the business community, big and small, were saying without exception. In the lead-up to the budget, I addressed and attended well over 100 small business meetings around Australia. The same message was given to me in unequivocal terms: get the budget deficit down, take the pressure off interest rates. In all of the budget discussions in which I was involved, the bottom line from the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Finance Minister (Mr Beazley) was to get the deficit down and, if possible, get it into surplus. We got it into surplus. We have created a structural surplus for the next three to four years so that the pressure would be off interest rates. Who is the biggest—
—Liar?

—No. Who will be the biggest beneficiary from having interest rates remain stable or having them go down? It will be small business. Also, consumer confidence will increase. When consumer confidence increases, the biggest beneficiaries are small business. Overwhelmingly, people spend their money in small business—directly and indirectly. Interest rate stability means that not only direct investment improves but also consumer confidence improves. The bottom line is that, as small business improves, their turnover improves and their profit improves. That is what the bottom line of the budget was about. That is what we were doing to support small business. That is what they demanded we do, and we delivered.

PARA.TAB: Although those opposite have not read the budget papers properly, they will note that the range of business assistance programs in the industry, science and technology portfolio and in the DEET portfolio were not affected. They were not cut back, as were programs in many other areas. Again, the government recognised that these programs are there to assist the growth of small business. A complete new program came through the DEET portfolio—$30 million over three years to fund enterprise development centres to encourage people to become self-employed and become operators of small business. Eighty enterprise development centres around Australia will be funded and will have access to funds to provide facilities to encourage small business development and expansion in their area. That was an absolutely new policy.

Another successful program over the last four years has been the export access program. We have spent close to $20 million over the last four to five years in helping small business become export oriented. Other 1,000 firms have gone through that program, and nearly 90 per cent of them have an export order. The interesting part of that program is that, though we fund it, it is administered and operated by business industry groups and business associations. They were very strong in their support for continuing that program. We have continued funding for another four years. Another $14 million will be available over four years. (Quorum formed)

The export access program has proved very successful and is supported by the business community, which manages the scheme. It has been very successful in getting many small businesses into the export market. That program was supported in this budget. For the opposition to say that the Prime Minister is not interested in small business is an outright lie. He set the parameters for this budget to get the deficit down and to take the pressure off interest rates. The business enterprise programs were basically left untouched. I again ask the opposition: what are you going to do for small business? What are your election promises? What are your policies? You do not have one in any of these areas. You get up and mouth rhetoric and make personal attacks on the Prime Minister of the most outrageous and slanderous kind all over the country, yet you do not put up one idea to help small business. For that, you should be eternally ashamed.

There is also the maintenance of the eight per cent provisional tax uplift factor. That is more than twice the rate of inflation and will hit small businesses in particular. There is an 80 per cent reduction in the threshold level for remitting PAYE tax on a twice-monthly basis. That threshold has been lowered from a remittance of $5 million to $1 million. A huge net of small businesses will be swept up in that difficult law. The budget will force a lot of subcontractors into the PAYE tax system.

The budget, as has been confirmed by many commentators, will do very little to reduce the upward pressure on interest rates, the great killer of small businesses. This budget has been a complete blind; the underlying budget deficit is still enormously high and there is no activity on the fiscal front to bring about, through this budget, a sustained reduction in pressures on interest rates. That is bad news for small business.

One of the worst things that has occurred in this budget is the 12 per cent sales tax that has been applied to builders hardware and building materials. The budget says that sales tax will apply to presently exempt goods such as screws, nails, paint, putty, adhesives, wallpaper, ceramic and glass, floor and wall tiles, and so on. A whole range of goods which previously have been tax exempt are now going to be taxed at the 12 per cent rate. This is nothing more than a GST by stealth but, unlike the GST we promised at the last election, there is absolutely no compensation for this 12 per cent tax. The government is clearly engaged in the gradual expansion of the sales tax net. You can bet your bottom dollar that if this government were to remain in office—which, fortunately, is not going to happen—it would inevitably extend the range of items to which this sales tax would apply.

This sales tax is very regressive because it will hit young first home buyers the most. They will be the worst affected. The HIA estimates that this tax is going to add $1,000 to the price of an $80,000 home, 2 1/2 times the estimate the government has put on it. It must mean that fewer houses are going to be built and there will be far fewer renovations, which is a massive industry. There will be reduced income in the housing industry and more job losses.

In the context of this matter of public importance, we must remember that housing is very much a small business industry. New dwellings, renovations and so on are overwhelmingly the activity of small businesses. There are painters, carpenters, plumbers, electricians, contractors for roofing and so on. They are all small business men and women. The HIA estimates that 86 per cent of its 28,000 members are small businesses and three-quarters of new houses are built by small businesses. This is very much a small business industry which the government is hitting with the new 12 per cent GST by stealth.

The housing industry is already in decline, so on top of this tax, which will depress the industry further, there is clear evidence that this industry is on a downward spiral. Lending for housing has been falling every month since October. In February, it fell 26 per cent on the year before. Dwelling approvals are declining and have declined every month since November. They were down 23.9 per cent in April. So the statement by Mr Keating—or Dr Keating, as he now is—on small business, saying that they have `never had it so good', really sums up Labor's contempt for the huge range of small businesses in this country. I think it is Dr Keating's political suicide note. The small business sector of this country will completely reject him, his policies and his government when we vote in the federal election.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating's failure to appreciate that the success of small business is critical to the social and economic well-being of all Australians as demonstrated by his arrogant remarks and high taxing.

—This is a figure for the trade deficit. It takes exports as well as imports into account. The difference between imports and exports is $7 billion per year. Do we recognise that countries like Korea continue to protect their own markets? I note that Korea imported fewer than 4,000 vehicles for a market twice the size of Australia's last year while we imported 300,000 vehicles.

PARA.TAB: Recognising that our competitors still will not let our product in, how does our government react? Does it freeze tariffs to help those small businesses and jobs that depend on the car industry? No, it whacks the industry with more taxes. Clearly, that new low threshold will dramatically increase compliance costs for many small businesses, despite the fact that the government concedes that tax compliance costs for small business are already five to 10 times higher than for big business.

If people understand what happens in the Senate, understand the importance of this institution, understand the importance of having a forum where differing views can be presented other than in the other place—which is after all merely the electoral college of the government—people will realise that the Senate is not just a cherished institution to those of us who have the honour and the privilege of serving in it, but it should be a cherished institution of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: The national network of environmental lawyers, which is proposed in the justice statement, is a welcome first step in redressing the serious imbalance for community groups and individuals attempting to ensure protection of the environment through the legal system. Groups seeking legal advice, representation and litigation are often opposing interests that are extremely well resourced. New South Wales has the only full Environmental Defender's Office. Other states have very limited or no access and many groups and individuals rely on services provided by lawyers on a voluntary basis.

PARA.TAB: The Greens were very pleased to note the scope for other initiatives to be used in the interests of the environment. These measures, we believe, are an appropriate response to a strong and longstanding call from people all over Australia. Greater participation by the community in all aspects of decision making is of benefit for all in the community and for the government. However, the proposed funding for the national network is inadequate. It is not appropriate, in our view, for the government to provide minimal funding and rely so heavily on the goodwill of people committed to environmental justice to provide the remaining services for the public good.

The government has proposed a national network but it did not provide funding for national coordination as requested by the New South Wales Environmental Defender's Office. This organisation has in effect been acting as a national coordinating body for some years. In its submission to Access to Justice the New South Wales Environmental Defender's Office did not apply for increased funding for itself but did request funding to allow it to continue its existing national liaison and to coordinate this new national network.

This coordination is vital to ensure maximum benefit from limited resources, to avoid duplication of effort and to encourage communication. It will allow very valuable exchange of information on cases and precedents and provides support from others working in similar areas and under similar circumstances with equally limited resources. I believe it will be a first step to avoid unnecessary duplication.

There is some funding available for two community development officers. It is expected that they will play a coordinating role in relation to community legal centres. I urge the government to correct this oversight and make the requested funding available to ensure proper coordination.

It was also announced in the Justice Statement that the human rights and discrimination law centre would be established. The first task of the centre is to conduct a review of discrimination on the grounds of sexuality. This is a welcome move. However, it is still a second best process. The lesbian, gay and transgender community has been calling for a full review of discrimination by the Australian Law Reform Commission. Such a review would enable a comprehensive inquiry process to be established and would facilitate debate within the wider community about changes to the law. This is a very wide-ranging area of the law. The recent Law Reform Commission inquiry into equality before the law cost in the vicinity of $500,000.
