TALK.START.PARA: —The government's Justice Statement, as presented to the President of the Senate on 17 May, announced a number of very positive initiatives. Amongst those were the creation of a network of environmental lawyers, measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution, an allocation of funds to enable courts to develop charters setting out standards of efficiency and service, and an increase in the Commonwealth's contribution to legal aid. However, it should be said that this increase will not be enough to make up for the gradual decline in legal aid over the past five years.

PARA.TAB: Aside from these and some other positive initiatives, the Justice Statement has failed to tackle a number of hard issues. The first and most serious was its failure to make substantive reforms to the legal profession. Aside from allowing lawyers to advertise—an option that not many are taking up—the statement made little more than an airy commitment to making the legal profession more competitive or accountable to the public. Yet a key reason for the high cost of justice in this country is the inability of lawyers to regulate themselves properly.

For example, the legal profession controls the number of entrants into its market by determining who shall receive articles of clerkship or, in the case of college of law graduates, who shall fulfil the minimal employment requirements. These are needed before a law graduate is granted a full practising certificate. Thus, it is lawyers who determine how many lawyers there are. The conflict of interest is obvious, yet the Justice Statement did not even mention it.

The Justice Statement also did nothing to provide an independent complaints system against lawyers. Presently, lawyers are responsible for administering complaints against other lawyers in nearly all states. Once more, the conflict of interest is clear. The government fudged these issues by saying that it did not have the constitutional power to act.

The Democrats do not agree; the government does have jurisdiction to create an individual complaints mechanism for lawyers operating in both the Family Court and Federal Court and a similar power with respect to moneys in trust for federal matters. These would have been sound measures in their own right but also they would have established strong precedents for state governments to follow. Further, the government has obviously plenty of influence given that it provides a very significant proportion of legal aid to the states; sometimes over half of state legal aid is Commonwealth sourced.

Another shortcoming in the Justice Statement is the government's failure to commit itself to putting all Commonwealth laws and regulations, the constitution and parliamentary debates on the Internet. The Democrats believe that the wide availability of information about our laws and system of government is absolutely essential, particularly at a time when smaller public libraries around the country are being closed in the name of economic efficiency.

As I have mentioned before, the network of environmental lawyers is excellent. However, the government has done nothing to address the fact that legal aid is only available for environmental disputes in two states. As has been mentioned by Senator Chamarette, no funds have been allocated for the national coordination of the network of environmental lawyers.

Coming back to the legal aid for environmental cases, at the moment a branch of the Attorney-General's Department determines when and how much money shall be granted for test cases in this area. In cases where the government is a litigant, such as the guns/woodchip licence challenge, the potential for conflict of interest is obvious.

The Democrats are also concerned about the government's promise to consult before statutory rules and regulations are created where those regulations affect business and business only. It neglected to mention that in so doing it was specifically rejecting a recommendation of the Administrative Review Council that consultation occur in the drafting of all statutory regulations except in limited circumstances. The government is therefore declaring that regulations that affect business are worthy of consultation but those that affect, for example, immigration, defence, child support and food standards are not.

A further criticism is that the Justice Statement made no reference to prison reform. This is despite the fact that Australian prisons are now little more than holding pens. Tied grants should have been targeted towards prison officer training, rehabilitation programs, halfway houses and other infrastructure such as libraries. Given that two-thirds of prisoners in this country are likely to re-offend, the idea of a safer Australia without prison reform is ridiculous.

The human rights research law centre is to be established and that is welcome. However, the amount of $50,000 that has been allocated for the inquiry into the discrimination suffered by gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people is hopelessly inadequate. One would have thought that at this stage the government would have seen the importance of this issue and allocated funds which would have given this particular inquiry a reasonable chance of success.

One other issue should be mentioned. In respect to the measures foreshadowed for family law reform, care must be taken in an attempt to produce more equitable results. Changes to the law and property division must be based not only on contributions made to a marriage but also on future needs of the separating partners. That needs a lot more emphasis in the legislation that is now before us. In particular, the responsibilities of primary care givers must be taken into account.

In conclusion, while many features of the Justice Statement are worthwhile and deserve praise and support, the statement could have been a lot better. In particular, it could have taken on the privileged profession that has given us so many politicians.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I note recommendation No. 1 by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which, as I understand it, was unanimous. It recommended in that instance that the resources available to the legislature be substantially increased so that, among other things, it can better assess the impact of legislation and its committees can better function. PARA.TAB: We have recently seen funding to the Senate standing committees and select committees slashed in the order of 37 per cent. The legal and constitutional affairs committee—I deal with both the legislation committee and the references committee—has had its funding cut in half. This unanimous recommendation from the committee, which was looking at the cost of justice and matters attendant thereto, was concerned that legislation was going through the parliament of Australia without adequate scrutiny and that part of this essential scrutiny is the Senate committee system.

The government response was that resource matters for parliamentary committees are for the parliament to decide. Remuneration issues for parliamentary office-holders are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. That is not a response. The government is entirely shirking the issue by saying that resources are for the parliament to decide. In this instance, the government has slashed the funding available to be applied to the various committees. That is a very effective way of muzzling any input from the coalition, the minor parties and even from Senator Schacht's colleagues on his side.

The government fails to remember that there are occasions when the minister has asked for a bill to be referred to a Senate committee. So it is not just the coalition that the government says uses these committees to indulge in troublemaking; the other parties and the independents in this chamber have referred various bills to those committees as well, all for very good reason. The people of Australia, via the Senate committee system, can have better scrutiny of the legislation before this parliament. So it was that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended on a unanimous basis that there be better resources for these very important reasons.

But the government simply said, `It is for parliament to decide what resources should be available.' I challenge the government to let parliament decide what amount should be appropriated for Senate committees. Let us decide that. If, as it said in its response, it is for us to decide, why not leave that to the parliament, and we will make that necessary appropriation?

We have not seen the government exercising some fiscal control there. But when it comes to the Senate committee system, which the government does not always get decisions from that it likes, it says that it is time to wield the block axe and slash funding. It is just not on.

It is not part of the democratic process to have the Senate committee system muzzled in this way. A most effective way of encroaching on the democratic system in this country is to cut the funding for these Senate committees. The government said that it is for the parliament to decide. In this case, the parliament did not decide; the government made the determination that the funding be cut. That is no response to what the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs recommended.

The committee system is a very good system. The respective committees work very hard. Time and again, I have heard government members in this chamber praise that system and join in reports which have been by consensus and unanimous. The people of Australia do not realise that in the committee system there is a good deal of agreement and common purpose. It is a shame that the government has seen fit to cut funding in this way. PARA.TAB: Firstly, let me put on my bipartisan hat and say that at last we are seeing something concrete from the government in response to the access to justice issue which, Mr Acting Deputy President, you will understand and which plenty of other senators, even those on the other side, will understand is an issue that was made a community issue by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. There is some debate about whether it was the now Acting Supreme Court Judge Spender QC or Don Chipp who first raised this matter, but it certainly was not a member of the government.

The matter was taken up by the parliamentary committee system, a system that is now having its resources trimmed. As soon as it became an issue in the community, as a result of the Senate addressing an issue of community concern, the Labor Attorney-General picked it up and said, with his hand over his heart, that he had always been concerned about it. Out came this big Justice Statement, for which many trees were cut down. While I do not deny that the statement contains some good things, if it represents the creative capacity of this government to address this issue, we are in for big trouble. There is no creativity and no innovation in this Justice Statement.

Tonight I want to refer to the number of re-announcements. I may not get through them all in time. This is meant to be the new direction forward but a good part of it simply looks back and announces what has already been done. It announces the introduction of legislation for greater certainty and fairness in the division of matrimonial property—first announced in December 1993. It announces the referral of powers from states in relation to de facto arrangements—also announced in 1993. It announces a competition policy to apply to the legal profession—already before the parliament and long ago agreed. It announces the establishment of a small taxation claims tribunal—a bill for which is already in the parliament.

Then there is corporate law simplification. That was a big announcement. We are already dealing with the first bill and other exposure drafts are already around. It announces a general commitment to simplifying laws. We have been on about plain English simplification of law for the 10 years I have been in the parliament. There is nothing new there. It announces a commitment to a legislative instruments bill. Forgive me, but I think that has already been through this chamber. It announces a model criminal code. We have been talking about that for 10 years and the first bill has already been through this chamber. Then there are the federal evidence laws, bills for which have already been through this chamber and the forensic procedures bill—the exposure draft for which is already out and being discussed in public.

I do not say anything for or against the substantive matters; I simply indicate that those are just the start of the re-announcements in this justice package. There is very little in here that is new. What is new is a lot more money for consultants, researchers, advisers. All those people will have jobs and will have no trouble gaining access to justice because they will be on good salaries. In the next couple of days I expect to see the Attorney-General's Department advertising 12 or 13 new positions to administer these new programs.

One of the most creative inquiries will be into the causes of crime. I wonder how many such inquiries there have been and why we suddenly feel we need a new one. It really highlights the barrenness of this government's capacity to deal with this issue. It also highlights its preparedness to go into flash packaging jobs—waving around a Justice Statement which it knows people will not have the time to read every page of—as a pre-election gimmick. When you take it apart and find all the re-announcements you cannot feel proud of what has been done.

There are some half measures. There is an enormous list of reviews and pilot programs which simply shows that the government is going to go on looking at problems without any idea of how to fix them. I intend to continue to push the point that while there are some, not many, good points in this statement, the best news is for bureaucrats, consultants and researchers. There is some good news for those people eligible for legal aid. But for the bulk of Australians, whose assets deprive them of access to legal aid and who are not as wealthy as some of the bankrupts that this government has let escape overseas, there is nothing. There is nothing here for the ordinary Australian who has a legal problem and who, because of a lack of finance, cannot access justice.

SPEECH.PARA: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill reflects the continuing commitment of this government to securing legitimate title to traditional lands on behalf of the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides a mechanism whereby traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory referred to in schedule 1 of that act may be granted to Aboriginal land trusts to hold title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since the act came into operation in 1977 a total of 59 separate parcels of land have been scheduled under the act.

The effect of this bill would be to bring within the schedule to the Land Rights Act that area of land which is the subject of the Western Desert repeat land claim. The Northern Territory Government, the Central Land Council and claimants in the land claim have entered into an agreement which settles that land claim. As part of that agreement the Northern Territory Government agreed to request the Commonwealth to exercise its powers under the Land Rights Act to grant the claim area, excluding the Tanami Road, to the traditional owners by scheduling that area under the Land Rights Act. The result of such scheduling would be that no further hearing or report by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner would then be necessary in order for the Aboriginal people concerned to be able to have the full rights of enjoyment of their traditional lands in fee simple.
The Government has the assurance of all parties to the negotiations that representative views of all Aboriginal people concerned have been obtained and their wishes taken into account.
There are no financial implications arising from this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1995 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1995 will give effect to the national heavy vehicle charges developed by the independent National Road Transport Commission to apply to vehicles registered under the federal interstate registration scheme.
Heads of government agreed in July 1991 to the establishment of the NRTC to develop nationally consistent charges and regulations for vehicles over 4.5 tonnes.

The NRTC released its heavy vehicle charges determination in June 1992. The Road Transport Charges (ACT) Act which gives effect to the charges in the act from 1 July 1995 and sets the model for other jurisdictions received royal assent in May 1992.

It is essential that inconsistent regulations and charges which continue to impede improvements in the efficiency of the road transport industry be changed to achieve a nationally uniform operating environment.
While agreement has been reached by state and territory ministers on the heavy vehicle charges, some states continue to be reluctant to implement them.
The proposed amendments will mean that FIRS vehicles registered in states where national charges have not yet been introduced will have access to the national charges.
In the interests of achieving national uniformity FIRS will apply only to vehicles over 4.5 tonnes and charges will no longer be able to be paid by instalments.
Money collected from these registration charges will continue to be returned to state and territory governments for the maintenance and upkeep of roads.

I now turn to the provisions of the bill. The principal amendments will remove the option to pay a registration charge based on actual distance travelled and the option to pay registration charges by instalments.

Further amendments will remove the references to motor vehicle and trailer charge monitoring devices. At present these devices are used to determine the actual distance that a vehicle has travelled in order to calculate the actual distance amount.
It is worth noting that reliable distance-only measuring devices are not currently available in Australia.
These changes reflect the arrangements for registration charges determined through the NRTC process.

Consequential amendments are required to the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985. The proposed amendments will include the registration charges for various vehicle types as a schedule to that act.
The implementation of national charges for heavy vehicles is a crucial step in the reform of the road transport industry.

The proposed amendments demonstrate the federal government's commitment to the harmonisation of heavy vehicle charges and regulations and its recognition of the importance of the road transport industry to the economy.
The onus is now on the states and the NT to act on their commitment to implement the charges from 1 July 1995.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1995 will apply the national heavy vehicle registration charges developed by the National Road Transport Commission to vehicles registered under the federal interstate registration scheme.

By implementing the national charges for vehicles registered under FIRS, the Commonwealth is honouring its commitment under the heavy vehicles agreement and promoting the harmonisation of road transport charges and regulations. This is important in facilitating efficiency improvements in the road transport industry.
I now turn to the provisions of the bill. The principal amendment will provide the national registration charges developed through the NRTC process as a schedule to the act.

The amendments also provide that where a vehicle falls within two or more vehicle types for the purposes of the charges, the registration charge will be the higher or highest of the charges applicable.

The amendments further provide that the amounts of registration charges may be altered by the regulations. Such an alteration must not increase or decrease the amount for the previous year by more than 5 per cent.
The amendments are to come into force from 1 July 1995.
The net budgetary impact of the amendments will be nil.
This bill should be read in conjunction with the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1995.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1995

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to make a number of amendments to Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio legislation.

Amendments to the Migration Act 1958 give effect to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration—Report on Asylum, Border Control and Detention—temporarily extend the operation of the migration agents registration scheme, provide for changes to the incoming passenger card, and make other minor and technical amendments.

The joint standing committee report made a number of recommendations regarding the release from detention of persons who arrive in Australia without authorisation. Amongst other aspects, the committee expressed concern—in recommendations 10 and 11—that there should be a capacity to consider release where detention exceeded six months.

Many of the committee's recommendations have already been implemented. This bill implements the government's response to recommendations 10 and 11 by providing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with a non-compellable discretion to determine that a person is an `eligible non-citizen'. Such persons are then able to apply for a bridging visa, which authorises their release from detention. The power to make the determination must be exercised by the Minister personally.

If the minister decides to exercise the power, the minister must table a statement in parliament setting out the determination and referring particularly to the reasons why the determination is in the public interest. Part 3 of the Migration Act 1958 provides a comprehensive registration scheme to regulate the conduct of migration agents.

This part of the act is subject to a `sunset clause' whereby the registration scheme will cease in September 1995, after having operated for 3 years. The proposed one year extension of the scheme until September 1996 will allow the Government time to consider the forthcoming report on the scheme by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, and provide time for the passage of any legislative changes. The Committee's report is expected in June 1995.

Section 506 of the Migration Act 1958 stipulates that regulations are to provide for information to be given on a passenger card. Subsection 506(2) requires that all non-citizens travelling to Australia, unless exempted, must answer the questions on the passenger card. Subsection 506(3) requires that certain questions be included on the card.

The proposed amendment to subsection 506(3) will allow greater flexibility with passenger cards, which will assist the streamlining of passenger entry into Australia. It will remove the present obligation to require all people completing the passenger card to answer questions relating to all the matters provided in subsection 506(3).

The adult migrant english program, AMEP, provides tuition in English as a second language to migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds. Tuition is provided to a functional level, sufficient to facilitate employment and achieve personal settlement goals. Current legislation requires the Commonwealth to provide free AMEP tuition to holders of certain types of visas. The amendment to the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 would exclude from that entitlement persons who hold permanent visas through having satisfied the principal applicant criteria for Class 816 or Class 818 entry permits—under the Migration (1993) Regulations.

On 1 November 1993 the government announced changes to provide access to permanent residence to—amongst others—better qualified asylum-seekers; and persons who held, or were eligible for, concessional entry permits providing humanitarian extensions of stay for people from Sri Lanka and the former Yugoslavia; and certain persons who held higher education qualifications, or had undertaken study towards them. Such persons could apply for Class 816 or 818 entry permits.

When approving the introduction of the new classes, the government considered that principal applicants would either need to demonstrate a capacity to communicate in English, or have English language proficiency sufficient to have undertaken or completed studies in Australia. Those persons should have no need to access the AMEP.

This amendment will exclude those seeking access, and discontinue access to those already receiving tuition. Departmental records at early May show that of almost 6,000 principal applicants approved so far, around 400 persons have accessed the AMEP.

The Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 was introduced at the same time as the Migration Reform Act 1992, as part of a package of measures designed to improve the effectiveness of Australia's control of its borders and the regulation of the entry, detention and removal of people who have no entitlement to remain. It was intended that the tax—payable by certain persons who obtain a visa after being unlawfully in Australia—would act as a disincentive to people remaining unlawful for long periods. The legislation was not intended to raise revenue.

It is the government's view that the objectives of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 are being effectively achieved through other legislative and procedural mechanisms. Since the introduction of the Migration Reform Act 1992, very limited classes of visas can be granted to persons unlawfully in Australia when they apply. Unlawful non-citizens face mandatory detention and removal by force of law, and bear the responsibility for associated costs.

Other initiatives implemented in the Migration Reform Act 1992 have progressed and streamlined compliance mechanisms. Additionally, increased investment in the compliance area has resulted in a significant improvement in a number of key indicators of compliance with migration laws. Against this background, the objectives of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 are no longer regarded as necessary for the successful achievement of compliance strategy.

Repeal of that tax act is proposed with retrospective effect to the date of its commencement. The numbers of applicants liable for the tax are few. Retrospective repeal would ensure that no persons would be liable for the tax, and is considered the most equitable course of action. It is proposed that any debts payable under the act be extinguished, and that a refund provision be provided. The projected revenue loss is negligible. I commend this bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst speaking to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1995, I take this opportunity to make some general comments about the integrity of the system we have operating in Australia. This legislation adopts recommendations from the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters relating to public funding for election campaigns. Having been involved in a number of campaigns, I am only too well aware of their costs. I have been the campaign director in a federal electorate for four federal election campaigns. I have been the state campaign director for two electoral campaigns. I do have an understanding of the complexities required to recoup some of those electoral costs. Having said that, I believe the same level of scrutiny does not apply to the integrity of the rolls. I understand Senator Tierney and others have made comments about this issue previously.

PARA.TAB: I have raised this matter before, particularly after the last federal election when there were a number of concerns about the legitimacy of some people claiming to be on the electoral roll for certain seats. The electoral commissioner has assured me that they do all things necessary to ensure the purity and accuracy of the rolls. However, I would like to tell two stories that suggest this accuracy is not all that it might be. For obvious reasons the names of the people involved in this exercise will remain unknown. For an election, a person whom we shall call Nigel Nichol Langford Black was registered to vote. His occupation was listed as leading hand. His address was given, and it was accurate—as was his name and occupation. For the same election, I understand a Samuel Bach was registered to vote. His name and address were also accurate. Neither Nigel Black nor Samuel Bach voted at that particular election. There is a very good reason for their not doing so. Nigel Black is a donkey, and Sam Bach is a dog. There was no difficulty in getting those names onto the electoral roll. It would have been very easy for persons claiming to be Nigel Black and Sam Bach to have turned up and voted. Most probably they could have voted five or six times at different polling places. TALK.START.PARA: —Today I gave notice of a motion concerning the very fast train project that was on the national agenda from the late 1980s until the early 1990s. It was first talked about seriously in about 1989. Since the early 1990s, it has silently slipped off the agenda.
—Off the rails.

—Yes, it has. The very fast train was to have run between Sydney and Melbourne on an especially designed track. Travelling at speeds of 350 kilometres an hour it would have been the fastest train in the world. The Sydney-Melbourne journey would have taken just three hours. It was expected that 30 trains a day would run each way. It was going to be an extraordinarily effective people mover at a very reasonable cost to the users of the service.

PARA.TAB: The project was to have been built by a consortium that included some of Australia's biggest companies: BHP; Elders; TNT; and the Japanese construction company Kumagai Gumi. The VFT project would have been the biggest project since the Snowy Mountains development and one of the most impressive projects since the Second World War. Construction of the VFT would have had an economic impact in the same manner as any major construction has; that is, a direct demand for labour and materials and a flow-on in indirect activity. Operation of the VFT would have supported direct economic activity along the route associated with the train's operations and track, and rolling stock maintenance. There would also have been indirect impacts, for instance, by changing the pattern of geographic accessibility.

The VFT has the potential to affect decisions on industrial location, residential location and market size across a range of economic sectors. Tourism, especially with the Olympic Games only 4 1/2 years away, would have been a great winner by increasing access to activities along the route. North-eastern Victoria would have greatly benefited from the original proposals, most noticeably the snow fields, wineries and water-based recreation activities around Lake Eildon.

All this would have come to pass if more imagination and commitment had been shown by the federal Labor government. The project was killed because the federal government refused to consider tax breaks for the developers. They wanted no financial assistance—having done their sums—except that they considered that tax holidays or concessions were needed. It was, and potentially still is, a very impressive project which would have very great benefits for us in terms of the tyranny of distance and linking our major capital cities.

Before the 1993 election, the coalition offered tax concessions to ensure that this valuable project would go ahead. I feel very strongly that, with the Olympics and the turn of the century just 4 1/2 years away, it should be placed back on the public agenda because an efficient national transport system is essential to ferry between Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra the hundreds of thousands of domestic and international visitors who will come for the Olympics.

It is a scheme that should still be seen as a national project. It should be embraced, as was the Snowy Mountains scheme, as being of long-term benefit to Australia. The Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure tabled a report in March 1991 on the proposed VFT project. The question, from the consortium's point of view, of financing the project came before the committee. The groups involved clearly said that it was a private project and they were not looking for government funding. However, the issue of incentive by way of tax arrangements was raised. At the time, committee member Senator Margaret Reid raised the prospect of the government's looking at whether or not tax incentives or tax arrangements ought to be put in place to ensure the project went ahead. That did not specifically favour a particular national project, but any project of this kind which was clearly in the national interest, as this one would be.

The federal cabinet, under Bob Hawke, supported the project but failed to deliver when it came to providing a reasonable economic environment for such a project to proceed. Some doubt was expressed as to whether Australia had sufficient population to generate the number of passengers to provide sufficient revenue to make the project profitable for investors. I believe there would be enough passengers to make it profitable; and the projections show that would be the case. I have no doubt that in the future, as our population grows, we will have sufficient population to make this project even more profitable. In terms of national infrastructure, it would be well worth getting the project off the ground now so it is in place as the population increases and economic activity develops.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 27 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that Energy Resources of Australia (ERA), surrounded by the World Heritage Area of Kakadu National Park, has made an application to release a large volume of contaminated water into the Magela Creek system and that the traditional owners downstream of the proposed release area are against this release.
(2) Is the Minister and the Office of Supervising Scientists taking their objection into consideration when making a final decision about the application.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the uranium mine was designed as a no release mine and that the traditional owners and affected peoples downstream are alarmed and distressed about the proposed contaminated water release.

(4) Is the Minister aware that the Plan of Management for Kakadu National Park states that `in all Environmental Impact Assessments the views and interests of Aboriginal traditional owners are considered as integral components of the assessment procedure'.
(5) Will the ERA's application for the release of contaminated water be supported; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of ERA's application to release water into Magela Creek, and that there have been objections by some Aboriginal people. There has been extensive consultation on this matter with the Northern Land Council, as the representative of the traditional owners. The Northern Land Council responded to the Northern Territory Government concerning the application.
ERA does not now propose to release water during the 1994-95 wet season except in the unlikely event of cyclonic rainfall conditions.
(2) The Supervising Scientist took into account objections to the proposed release before providing advice to the Northern Territory Government.
(3) See (1) above.
I am advised that the Ranger mine was not designed as a no-release mine. The issue of water management at the Ranger mine was considered at some length

ANSWER.PARA: by the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, which took into account the views and interests of traditional owners. Based on the recommendations of the inquiry, subsequent research and community consultation, a policy has been adopted that release of water into Magela Creek will only be considered for very wet years of 1 in 10 rainfall intensity. This policy is regarded as constituting best practicable technology.

PARA.TAB: Any water released from the Ranger mine will be diluted so that the water quality downstream of the mine will not significantly affect the environment. Extensive testing by the Environmental Research Institute of the Supervising Scientist shows that water released from Ranger will not harm the natural ecosystem or pose a threat to the health of people living or gathering food downstream of the mine.

(4) I am aware of the requirements of the Plan of Management for Kakadu National Park. The Ranger mine occupies a lease outside the Park. The Supervising Scientist has advised me that the environment of Kakadu National Park would not be significantly affected by the proposed release.
(5) See (3) above.

The Supervising Scientist has advised me that controlled release to Magela Creek, from a scientific viewpoint, would have been the best method for disposal of excess water to achieve a high level of environmental protection. Accordingly he provided advice to the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy supporting ERA's application, provided appropriate conditions were met, including:
a minimum creek flow for dilution purposes;
a dilution level of water based on biological and chemical tests; and
a suitable monitoring program to be in force throughout the release.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 February 1995:

(2) Australia Post is empowered to disclose personal information, including name and address information, to third parties in accordance with Privacy Principle 11 of the Privacy Act 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 15 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) Has D-Ram Pty Ltd of Queensland brought product samples of the stun gun manufactured by the United States firm Air Taser Inc to Australia for testing and Government evaluation;
(b) have product samples been shown to Government officials; and
(c) is documentation being prepared to obtain import approval.
(2) (a) Is the Government interested in acquiring stun guns; if so, for whom in particular and for what purpose and use;
(b) is the Government interested in manufacturing parts of stun guns or manufacturing the stun guns themselves; and
(c) would this weapon be suitable for use in the Australian Defence Force or in the Police Force.
(3) (a) What are the precise specifications of this stun gun;
(b) what is the status of this gun; and
(c) how does it work?
(4) Detail the approval process so far for allowing product samples of these weapons to enter Australia.
(5) (a) Detail the approval process for the Air Taser stun gun to be imported into Australia as a product for wider distribution; and
(b) to what stage has the process advanced.
(6) (a) What testing and criteria is being used to decide whether the guns should be imported into Australia;
(b) what testing and evaluation is being carried out; and
(c) will the results of this testing and evaluation be made available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by the Australian Customs Service that no official record exists of D-Ram Pty Ltd of Queensland importing a sample unit of an Air Taser stun gun. Nor has an import approval been sought of ACS by the company in question. Following inquiries in Queensland, my advice is that no product samples have been shown to Government officials.

(2) As part of the Government's response to the recommendations of the National Committee on Violence Report 1990, there has been considerable attention given to identifying and evaluating alternative measures to lethal force used by police officers in the course of their duties. The National Police Research Unit (NPRU) is conducting a national project which is investigating some of these alternatives. A report on the project should be available to the Australasian Police Ministers' Council (APMC) later this year. I am advised that, to date, no testing of stun guns has been conducted as part of the research. I am therefore unable to comment on the suitability of the weapon for use in police forces. As for the use of stun guns in the Australian Defence Force, I believe this element of the question is best directed to the Honourable Minister for Defence.

(3) I am advised that stun guns come in two basic designs. One is hand-held similar to a torch with two electronic probes attached to the front of it. The unit is pushed against the body and activated, working in similar fashion to a cattle prod. The second is like a small handgun which fires two darts, connected to lengths of conductive cable, into the body of the subject at which time the charge is activated. The precise specifications of the Air Taser stun gun are not known, but the name implies it is operated with compressed air as a means for shooting the electric probes.

(4) The Australian Customs Service (ACS) has advised that importation of product samples of these weapons would be treated in the same manner as individual or commercial imports of a standard unit. Stun guns are prohibited imports under Schedule 2 Item 12 of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Importation of stun guns is prohibited unless permission in writing is given by the Minister responsible for Customs. Applications for permission to import would need to be accompanied by written support for the importation of these items from the relevant State or Territory police authority, stating that the importer complies with all state or territory laws and requirements. I have been advised by the ACS however, that imports for the Commonwealth are not bound by the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and therefore no permission to import is required to be issued to Commonwealth Government agencies. I have been further advised that, in the past, a standing authorisation by the Minister responsible for Customs has been granted for importation by or on behalf of State or Territory police authorities. Any further information in relation to the importation of and permission to import these items should be sought from the Minister responsible for Customs.

(5) Imports for wider distribution of the Air Taser stun gun would be as per the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. I have been advised by the ACS that, at this stage, no such permission has been granted by the Minister responsible for Customs or sought of the ACS.
(6) As stated earlier, no testing of stun guns is being undertaken on behalf of the Australian Government for the purposes of law enforcement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 4 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Federal Government provide additional funds to supplement those provided by the Government of Western Australia for damage caused to horticultural properties in Carnarvon by tropical cyclone Bobby.
(2) Is the Government aware that many properties in Carnarvon suffered severe erosion of top soil as a result of tropical cyclone Bobby.
(3) What rural relief or emergency relief funding is available to assist people who are significantly affected by a natural disaster in terms of their economic livelihood.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) The Commonwealth Government considers the need for natural disaster assistance upon receipt of a request from an affected State or Territory under either the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements or the exceptional circumstances provisions of the Rural Adjustment Scheme. No such request for assistance has been received from the Western Australian Government in respect of tropical cyclone Bobby. Nor has the Western Australian Government apprised the Commonwealth of associated damage and losses.

(3) Under the Rural Adjustment Scheme, governments provide support to farmers in cases of exceptional circumstances, which could not reasonably be expected to be accommodated within a farmer's normal risk management activities. Exceptional circumstances assistance is provided by the Commonwealth and an affected State or Territory by way of subsidies for interest payable on existing and new loans supplied by a commercial institution. Eligible farmers may receive interest rate subsidies of up to 100 per cent to facilitate strategies such as improvements in productivity, the provision of carry-on finance, or debt restructuring.

Decisions on requests for exceptional circumstances support are made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who may seek advice from the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, an independent body established to provide expert advice to the Minister after consultation with all interested parties.

Under the Natural Disaster Relief Arrangements, the Commonwealth provides financial assistance to State and Territory governments, in accordance with an agreed funding formula, for the costs of relief and restoration associated with the occurrence of eligible natural disasters.

In addition, in the event of a natural disaster that causes severe and widespread damage to property and a significant number of deaths, serious illnesses or serious injuries, the Commonwealth may make one-off distress relief payments directly to individuals under the Disaster Relief Payment provisions of the Social Security Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a media statement issued by the acting Minister for Defence on 21 April 1995 relating to allegations contained in a letter published in the Australian Aviation magazine, May 1995, concerning the use of a Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Falcon 900 VIP aircraft:
(1) What were the dates and times of departure and arrival of the two flights involved, and what were their total costs including a breakdown of those costs.
(2) (a) What rank was the officer who approved the second flight; (b) what position did he hold; and (c) on what basis did he give the approval.
(3) Who asked for the second RAAF flight to pick up the documents, and on what authority.
(4) Is it a requirement that all Special Purpose flights require the approval of the Minister; if so, why was it not sought in this case.

(5) What other Special Purpose flights have been authorised without ministerial approval in the past 3 years and if flights have been authorised by other than the Minister, were they listed in the published Special Purpose flight schedules.

(6) When were the `appropriate procedures' referred to by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Punch) to prevent any further occurrences of this nature, put in place and is it correct that `appropriate procedures' were already in place.
(7) Were the documents in fact collected by the second aircraft or had they already been despatched on a civilian flight; if so; why was the second RAAF flight not informed and returned to base.
(8) What was the specific crew training conducted on the return journey to Canberra.
(9) How many total hours did the crew of the second aircraft serve on that shift.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No incident has been identified which relates to the honourable senator's question. However, in 1992 an incident did occur which was similar. I will address your questions to that incident.

The first aircraft, a VIP flight tasked to pick up the Treasurer, departed Canberra on 1 August 1992 at 1320 hrs Eastern Standard Time (EST) and arrived in Perth at 1600 hrs Western Standard Time (WST). The aircraft departed Perth on 2 August 1992 at 0530 hrs WST and arrived in Canberra 1055 EST. Total flying time was 7.9 hrs at a total cost of $25,675 (at a cost recovery rate of $3,250 per hr).

The second aircraft departed Canberra on 1 August 1992 at 2100 hrs EST on a training flight and arrived in Perth at 2340 hrs WST. This aircraft departed Perth on 2 August 1992 at 1300 hrs WST, arriving at Laverton 1750 hrs EST, departing Laverton at 1830 hrs EST and arriving at Canberra at 1920 hrs EST. Total flying time was 8.2 hrs at a total cost of $26,650.
(2) (a) Squadron Leader.
(b) No 34 Squadron Tasking Officer.
(c) The officer made his own decision to utilise a squadron pilot training flight to forward Treasury documents, which had been left off the VIP flight in Canberra, to the Treasurer.
(3) There was no request made for the second flight. The Tasking Officer made the decision on his own initiative to deliver the documents after discovering they had been left behind.

(4) Yes. However, the second flight was not a Special Purpose flight. 34 Squadron conducts a number of tasks including training flights, maintenance test flights and other military tasks such as providing transport to support Australian operations in Somalia and the Gulf.

(5) All Special Purpose flights have been authorised by the Governor-General, the Prime Minister or myself, and are listed in the published Special Purpose flight schedules. Other tasks such as training and maintenance flights do not appear in the published flight schedules.

(6) Appropriate procedures were put in place by the issue of a Flying Order shortly after the second (training) flight in 1992. There were procedures already in place prior to the flight but there was no second check to ensure that a task had been approved by the Commanding Officer or the Executive Officer. The new procedure requires the aircraft captain to ensure that he or she has the personal approval of the Commanding Officer or the Executive Officer before proceeding on a cross-country training flight.
(7) The documents were collected by the second aircraft and transported to Perth. No civil aircraft were involved.
(8) The co-pilot was trained in air route flying as a captain under training. Training in short field landings was also conducted on the short runway at RAAF Laverton.
(9) Total crew time for the second aircraft was 7.4 hrs on 1 August 1992 and 10.5 hrs on 2 August 1992.
